questions.text: A patient made a self-diagnosis of athlete’s foot (Tinea pedis) and began using a product advertised on television. The condition improved but did not clear and then the patient showed himself to a Dermatologist. A skin scraping was sent to the laboratory for culture, including culture for fungi. The fungal culture yielded a slow-growing colony, which produces abundant microconidia. This is consistent with isolation of a dermatophyte of which of the following genera?
questions.solution:
• This is consistent with isolation of a Trichophyton.
  • Dermatophytes can be identified by their colonial appearance and microscopic morphology after growth for 2 weeks at 25°C on Sabouraud’s dextrose agar.
  • Differential diagnosis of Dermatophytes on the basis of Macroconidia and microconidia.

DERMATOPHYTES / CUTANEOUS INFECTIONS:

  • Group of filamentous Fungi that infect only superficial Keratinized tissues skin, hair & nails.
  • Clinical conditions: Tinea or ringworm

General characteristics of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes:

General Microconidia Macroconidia
Trichophyton Abundant microconidia, arranged in clusters along hyphae Relatively scanty, elongated with blunt ends (Pencil shaped), thin-walled
Microsporum Rare, Single microconidia (multicellular) Numerous, Single macroconidia (multicellular) spindle-shaped, thick-walled, rough
Epidermophyton No microconidia Club shaped or boat shape

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with hematochezia. She was admitted to another hospital when this symptom developed two weeks previously. Her medical history included a huge hepatic hemangioma detected eight years previously. The most likely diagnosis for this patient would be:
questions.solution:
Kasabach-Merritt syndrome

  • A rare but life-threatening complication of hemangioma, characterized by consumptive coagulopathy with large vascular tumors.
  • More than 80% of Kasabach-Merritt syndrome cases occur within the first year of life. However, there are few reports of Kasabach-Merritt syndrome with giant hepatic hemangioma in adults.
  • The most important treatment for this syndrome is the removal of the large vascular tumor. However, surgical treatment entails the risk of bleeding, and the patient’s condition can mitigate against surgery.

Liver Hemangioma

  • MC benign tumor of the liver.
  • Mainly seen in women of 45 years.
  • Small capillary hemangiomas (no clinical significance), larger cavernous hemangiomas
  • Usually single and <5 cm in diameter, occur equally in right & left liver.
  • Giant hemangioma: Lesions >5 cm

Clinical Features

  • Most commonly asymptomatic and incidentally found on imaging studies.
  • Large compressive masses may cause vague upper abdominal symptoms.
  • Kasabach-Merritt syndrome: Syndrome of thrombocytopenia & consumptive coagulopathy, rarely seen
  • LFTs & tumor markers are normal

questions.text: The following test is performed on the patient with low backache All are true about the condition except?

choices.text: Distance between two points increases by <5cm in lumbar flexion

questions.solution:
• The image shows modified Schober test being done to evaluate for ankylosing spondylitis.
  • In cases with restriction of chest wall motion, decreased vital capacity and increased functional residual capacity are common.
  • This distance increases by > 5 cm and in the case of normal mobility and by <4 cm in the case of decreased mobility.
  • Chest expansion is measured as the difference between maximal inspiration and maximal forced expiration in the fourth intercostal space in males or just below the breasts in females, with the patient’s hands resting on or just behind the head. Normal chest expansion is < 5 cm

questions.text: Following admission CTG was done for a woman on admission in the labor room shows:
questions.solution:
The above CTG shows late deceleration

Early decelerations :

  • Uniform, repetitive, periodic slowing of FHR with onset early in the contraction and return to baseline at the end of the contraction
  • The peak of the contraction coincides with the Nadir (lowest) of heart rate
  • Seen in head compression

Late decelerations :

  • Uniform, repetitive, periodic slowing of FHR with onset mid to end of the contraction and nadir more than 20 seconds after the peak of the contraction and ending after the contraction.
  • Seen in - Placental Insufficiency, Epidural analgesia, Maternal hypotension.

Variable decelerations :

  • Variable, intermittent periodic slowing of FHR with rapid onset and recovery.
  • Time relationships with contraction cycle are variable and they may occur in isolation.
  • Seen in- Cord compression

Prolonged deceleration :

  • An abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline that lasts at least 60–90 seconds.
  • These decelerations become pathological if they cross two contractions, i.e. greater than 3 minutes

questions.text: The structure of a protein is highly correlated to its function hence structure determination can reveal the function of a newly discovered protein. Which technique is most widely used to study structure of protein:
questions.solution:
• In the question, they have not mentioned the nature of structure such as 1o, 2o, or 3o, etc. In this case, consider tertiary structure (3D structure).
  • So, mark X-ray crystallography (X-ray crystallography can detect 3-D structure of any macromolecule).
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON THIS TOPIC

Mass spectrometry:

Best technique to determine → primary structure of proteins

  • This technique is Qualitative as well as Quantitative
  • Can detect post-translational modifications (like hydroxylation) or covalent modifications of enzymes (like phosphorylation and dephosphorylation)
  • Can detect the exact molecular weight of the protein (as the name says - MASS).

questions.text: Which of the following infections have been correlated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
• Risk factors for nasopharyngeal carcinoma include area of habitation, ethnicity, and tobacco use.
  • There is an increased incidence of nasopharyngeal cancer in southern China, Africa, Alaska, and in Greenland Eskimos.
  • A strong correlation exists between nasopharyngeal cancer and the presence of EBV infection, such that EBV titres may be used as a means to follow a patient’s response to treatment.

questions.text:
All of the following are True regarding mitochondrial DNA, except?

Linear double-stranded
Inherited from mother
Low mutation rate
All respiratory proteins are synthesized within mitochondria itself
questions.solution:
The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) has structural and functional resemblances with prokaryotic DNA

  • mtDNA is circular in nature and contains about 16,000 nucleotide bases
  • A vast majority of structural and functional proteins of the mitochondria are synthesized in the cytosol under the influence of nuclear DNA. However, certain proteins (around 13), most of them being the components of electron transport chain, are synthesized in the mitochondria (e.g. cytochrome b of complex lll, two subunits of ATP synthase.
  • mtDNA is inherited from the mother
  • Mitochondrial DNA is subjected to high rate of mutations (about 10 times more than nuclear DNA)
  • Diseases related to mitochondrial DNA
    • MELAS (mitochondrial encephalopathy lactic acidosis stroke-like episode)
    • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
    • Leigh syndrome
    • Kearns Sayre syndrome
    • NARP syndrome

questions.text: A gradual increase in threshold caused by prolonged slowly rising sub-threshold stimulus resulting from the inactivation of sodium channels, i.e., When a nerve is depolarized very slowly, the normal threshold may be passed without the firing of an action potential. Which one of the following is being described here?
questions.solution:
• Accommodation: refers to a gradual increase in threshold caused by prolonged slowly rising sub-threshold stimulus resulting from the inactivation of sodium channels, i.e., When a nerve is depolarized very slowly, the normal threshold may be passed without the firing of an action potential (option-2).
  • Adaptation: When a continuous sensory stimulus is applied, the receptor responds at a high impulse rate at first and then at a progressively slower rate until finally, the rate of action potentials decreases to very few or often to none at all (option-1).
  • Refractoriness: If the second stimulus applied during the refractory period of the first stimulus, the second stimulus fails to excite the tissue for one more time (option-3). While, in accommodation, the tissue fails to respond even for the first time.
  • Electrotonus: Dendrites fail to transmit action potentials because their membranes have relatively few voltage-gated sodium channels, and their thresholds for excitation are too high for action potentials to occur; refers to a passive spread of charge inside a neuron (option-4).

questions.text: A 35 years male presented to OPD with complain of mild pain abdomen. There is no history of fever, diarrhea, vomiting or any other GI symptom. He tells to doctor that he is suffering from this mild pain for last 6 months. O/E - He is normotensive, pulse = 72 bpm, no visible lymphadenopathy. All blood investigations were normal. CECT abdomen revealed suprarenal mass on Right side. A diagnosis of Adrenal Incidentaloma is made. Tumor is likely to be ?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Endocrine inactive tumor. Most common Adrenal incidentalomas are Endocrine inactive tumors (60-85%)

Prevalence of Adrenocortical Adenoma

  1. Endocrine inactive tumors : 60-85%
  2. Cortisol producing
  3. Aldosterone producing
  4. Pheochromocytoma : 5-10%.

Endocrine inactive tumors are also called as Non- functional tumors

questions.solution:
1. Cushing syndrome: causes impaired Glucose tolerance and hyperglycemia. The majority of patients also experience psychiatric symptoms, mostly in the form of anxiety or depression, but acute paranoid or depressive psychosis may also occur.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the anterior abdominal wall components is correct?

Conjoint tendon is formed by 2/3 of external oblique and 1/3 internal oblique
Inguinal ligament formed by aponeurosis of external oblique
Lacunar ligament is extension of inguinal ligament
Interfoveolar ligament related to conjoint tendon
questions.solution:
• Conjoint tendon is formed by internal oblique and transverse abdominis and not external oblique and internal oblique.

Other options:

  • Inguinal ligament is formed by aponeurosis of external oblique at its lower border.
  • Lacunar ligament is an extension of inguinal ligament and connects the inguinal ligament to the pectineal ligament near the point where they both insert on the pubic tubercle.
  • Interfoveolar ligament is related to conjoint tendon
  • Lateral to the conjoint tendon there is a ligamentous band originating from the lower margin of the transversalis fascia and extending down in front of the inferior epigastric artery to the superior ramus of the pubis ; it is termed the interfoveolar ligament of Hesselbach

questions.text:
A 40-days-old female baby born at 30 weeks of gestation with 1350 grams of weight was brought to the Ophthalmology unit for screening of Retinopathy of Prematurity. She was diagnosed with Stage 2 ROP & advised for weekly follow-up. Which of the following structures are derived from the embryonic layer similar to the structure discussed here?

Epithelial layers of iris
Sphincter & dilator pupillae muscles
Sheaths of optic nerve
Secondary vitreous
Ciliary muscle
questions.solution:
Retina is derived from Neural ectoderm. The other structures derived from the same embryonic layer are Epithelial layers of ciliary body, Epithelial layers of iris, Sphincter and dilator pupillae muscles, Optic nerve (neuroglia and nervous elements only), Melanocytes, Secondary vitreous, Ciliary zonules (tertiary vitreous)

STRUCTURES DERIVED FROM THE EMBRYONIC LAYERS:

1. Surface ectoderm

  • The crystalline lens
  • Epithelium of the cornea
  • Epithelium of the conjunctiva
  • Lacrimal gland
  • Epithelium of eyelids and its derivatives viz., cilia, tarsal glands and conjunctival glands
  • Epithelium lining the lacrimal apparatus.

2. Neural ectoderm

  • Retina with its pigment epithelium
  • Epithelial layers of ciliary body
  • Epithelial layers of iris z Sphincter and dilator pupillae muscles
  • Optic nerve (neuroglia and nervous elements only)
  • Melanocytes
  • Secondary vitreous
  • Ciliary zonules (tertiary vitreous)

3. Associated paraxial mesenchyme

  • Blood vessels of choroid, iris, ciliary vessels, central retinal artery, other vessels.
  • Primary vitreous
  • Substantia propria, Descemet's membrane and endothelium of cornea
  • ü The sclera
  • Stroma of iris
  • ü Ciliary muscle
  • Sheaths of optic nerve z Extraocular muscles
  • Fat, ligaments and other connective tissue structures of the orbit
  • Upper and medial walls of the orbit
  • Connective tissue of the upper eyelid

4. Visceral mesoderm of maxillary process below the eye

  • Lower and lateral walls of orbit
  • Connective tissue of the lower eyelid

questions.text: A 62-years-old diabetic female patient presented with a history of progressive right-sided weakness of one-month duration. The patient was also having speech difficulty. Fundus examination showed papilledema. Two months ago, she also had a fall in her bathroom and struck her head against a wall. The most likely clinical diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Chronic subdural hematoma

  • Chronic SDH: Collection of blood breakdown products that is at least 2-3 weeks old.
  • Chronic SDHs often occur in patients without a clear history of head trauma, as they may arise from minor trauma.

Clinical Features

  • Alcoholics, the elderly, and patients on anticoagulation are at higher risk for developing chronic SDH.
  • Patients may present with headaches, seizures, confusion, contralateral hemiparesis, or coma.

Treatment

  • A chronic SDH >1 cm or any symptomatic SDH should be surgically drained.
  • Chronic SDH typically consists of a viscous fluid, with a texture and dark brown color reminiscent of motor oil.
  • A simple burr hole can effectively drain most chronic SDHs.
  • The procedure is converted to open craniotomy if the SDH is too congealed for irrigation drainage, the complex of membranes prevents effective drainage, or persistent hemorrhage occurs that cannot be reached with bipolar cautery through the burr hole.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient having persistent allergic rhinitis, asthmatic episodes with peripheral hypereosinophilia. Histological findings are shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showseosinophil-rich vasculitis.

Churg-Strauss syndromeis a small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis classically associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomas.

Vascular lesions can be histologically similar to polyarteritis nodosa or microscopic polyangiitis but are also characteristically accompanied bygranulomas and eosinophils.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male is taken up for emergency laparotomy as he had a gunshot wound and was showing symptoms of hypotension and tachycardia. Which general anaesthetic would you pick for this case, given that it selectively inhibits excitatory NMDA receptors?
questions.solution:
Ketamine

  • Intravenousinducing agent.
  • Acts byblocking NMDAreceptors.
  • Adverse effects:Hallucinations, deliriumandvivid dreamsare importantadverse effectsthat are seen during recovery from anaesthesia (emergence delirium).
  • Has indirect sympathomimetic action ⇒ ↑ blood pressure, heart rate and cardiac output
  • Increases intraocular pressure and intracranial tension
  • Appropriate drug for anesthetizing patients, at high risk of bronchospasm

questions.text:
6 years old child presents to the hospital with multiple Café au lait spots associate with hamartomas in the iris. Which of the following statements is not correct about this condition?

This is a case of Neurofibromatosis-1 with the presence of lisch nodules in the iris
Cortical thickening of long bones may occur
MRI-brain reveals unidentified bright objects that tend to disappear with age
Can occasionally differentiate into a malignant nerve sheath tumor.
questions.solution:
• This is a case of Neurofibromatosis-1 with the presence of lisch nodules in the iris
  • Lisch nodules are hamartomas, best identified by slit-lamp examination
  • Cortical thinning of long bones may occur
  • MRI-brain reveals unidentified bright objects that tend to disappear with age
  • A neurofibroma can occasionally differentiate into a malignant nerve sheath tumor.

Neurofibromatosis

For the diagnosis, at least 2 of the following characteristics should be present,

  1. six or more café au lait spots (>5mm in prepubertal or >15mm in postpubertal)
  2. Two or more neurofibroma
  3. Freckling in axilla or groin
  4. Optic glioma
  5. Two or more lisch nodules
  6. Dysplasia of sphenoid or dysplasia or thinning of long bones
  7. First degree relative with NF1

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of glycogenolysis in sequence:

Formation of limit dextrins
Transfer of glucose residues from branched-chain to neighbouring straight-chain (Glucan Transferase)
Break down alpha (1→4) bond from non-reducing end
Break down of alpha (1→6) bond
questions.solution:
Break down alpha (1→4) bond from non-reducing end

↓

Formation of limit dextrins

↓

Transfer of glucose residues from branched-chain to neighbouring straight-chain (Glucan Transferase)

↓

Break down of alpha (1→6) bond

Glycogen Phosphorylase breaks alpha (1→4) bonds, starting from non-reducing end, till four glucose residues are left at branch point.
Glycogen Phosphorylase can break glucose residues in a chain only till 4 glucose residues are left in the branched-chain phosphorylase breaks only alpha (1→ 4) bonds and not alpha(1 → 6) bonds. The structure left is known as Limit Dextrin.
Glucan Transferase transfers 3 glucose residues from 1 chain to the neighbouring chain.(Oligo alpha (1 → 4 or alpha (1→ 4) glucan transferase or 4:4 transferase)
Debranching enzyme: Breaks a(1→ 6) bond, which is present at the starting of a branched-chain. This glucose is released in the form of free glucose. ( Amylo alpha (1→ 6) glucosidase )

questions.text: G3P2L2 at 40 weeks is in labour. The baby's head delivers but then retracts back against the perineum. McRoberts maneuver is done to delivers the anterior shoulder.In postnatal period , the right arm is hanging & limp to the baby’s side with the forearm extended and internally rotated.What is the likely reason ?
questions.solution:
• The above case history is suggestive of Shoulder dystocia for which McRoberts maneuver is done

BRACHIAL PLEXUS INJURIES

  • Shoulder dystocias can be associated with significant fetal morbidity including brachial plexus palsies, clavicular fractures, and humeral fractures. However, only half of the injuries are associated with shoulder dystocia.
  • Injury to the brachial plexus may be localized to the upper or lower roots.
  • Erb palsy and Klumpke paralysis may result from injury to the brachial plexus. In Erb (or Erb-Duchenne) palsy, the upper roots of the brachial plexus are injured (C5–6), resulting in paralysis of the shoulder and arm muscles; the arm hangs limply to the side and is extended and internally rotated.
  • In the case of Klumpke’s paralysis, the lower nerves of the brachial plexus are affected (C7–T1) and the hand is paralyzed.
  • Importantly, almost all of these injuries resolved by 1 year of life

questions.text:
Match the syndrome with the nerve involved





Pronator syndrome
Guyon’s Canal syndrome
Meralgia paraesthetica
Cheralgia Paraesthetica
Tarsal tunnel syndrome




Sciatic nerve
Posterior tibial nerve
Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Median nerve
Ulnar nerve
Superficial radial nerve
questions.solution:
Entrapment Syndrome Nerve Involved
Carpal tunnel syndrome Median Nerve (at wrist Common) – Phalen’s / Reverse Phalen’s Test
Pronator syndrome Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis or origin of pronator teres or FDS)
Cubital tunnel Syndrome Ulnar nerve (between two heads of flexor carpi ulnaris)
Guyon’s Canal syndrome Ulnar nerve (at wrist)
Thoracic outlet syndrome Lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels (between clavicle and first rib)
Piriformis syndrome Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paraesthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Tarsal tunnel syndrome Posterior tibial nerve (behind and below medial malleolus)
Morton’s metatarsalgia Interdigital nerve compression (Usually of 3rd, 4thtoe)
Cheralgia Paraesthetica Superficial radial nerve

questions.text: The bile salts are amphipathic compounds, synthesized in the liver and secreted via the gallbladder into the intestinal lumen for help in digestion and absorption of dietary fats. The precursor for Bile salt synthesis is:
questions.solution:
• Bile acids are synthesized from cholesterol (by modification of side chain), which is synthesized from Acetyl CoA.

  • Bile acids consist of Deoxycholic acid, Lithocholic acid, and Chenodeoxycholic acid.

  • Bile acids are more appropriately called bile salts
    • Present in deprotonated form
    • Made in liver (RLE is 7-a-Hydroxylase)
    • Stored in gallbladder,
    • Emulsify the dietary fat which increases the surface area.

questions.text: Chordee is seen in which of the following conditions shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Image A – Hypospadias

Image B – Priapism

Image C – Peyronies disease

  • Chordee is a condition where bands of tissue pull on the penis, making it appear bent or curved. This is particularly noticeable during erection. It usually occurs in children with hypospadias
  • The most common reason is that the penis does not develop properly in the womb. A skin defect, penis abnormality, or other defect is present that results in a curved appearance, which is most evident during erection.

Midgut:

Hindgut:

questions.text: Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels are encoded by four genes (HCN1,2,3,4) with HCN4 being widely expressed in the SA node. It has also been dubbed an “f” channel and the current produced as funny current. Which of the following is a function of these channels?
questions.solution:
• HCN channel is a Na+ channel (permeable to both Na+ and K+ ions, with increased permeability to Na+), consists of four either identical or non-identical subunits that are integrally embedded in the cell membranes of SA nodal cells to create an ion-conducting pore.
  • Also referred to as “h” channel (activated following hyperpolarization) and the current through the h channels is called “h” current (Ih), and because of its unusual (funny) activation, it has also been dubbed an “f” channel and the current produced as funny current.
  • A major contributor to pacemaker potential.
  • It is a type of metabotropic receptor associated channel activated by cyclic nucleotides (cAMP/cGMP) and more the hyperpolarization, more the activation of the channel.
  • HCN channels are encoded by four genes (HCN1,2,3,4) with HCN4 are widely expressed in the SA node.

questions.text:
The roof of the anatomical snuff box is formed by which of the following structures?

Cephalic vein and superficial branch of radial nerve
Basilic vein and superficial branch of radial nerve
Cephalic vein and radial artery
Basilic vein
questions.solution:
• Roof of anatomical snuff box is by cephalic vein and superficial branch of radial nerve.
  • The pulse of the radial artery is palpable in the floor of the snuffbox against scaphoid bone.

Boundaries of Anatomical snuff box

  • Posteromedial (ulnar border) - extensor Pollicis longus
  • Anterolaterally (radial border) - extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus.
  • Floor - scaphoid, trapezium, base of 1st metacarpal and styloid process of radius.
  • Content - radial artery (Pulse can be felt by palpating radial artery against scaphoid bone).

questions.text: A 29-year-old fit male was scheduled for finger reimplantation following traumatic amputation. Anaesthesia was induced with thiopentone 4 mg/kg body weight followed by succinycholine 80 mg and tracheal intubation and was then maintained with nitrous oxide and oxygen supplemented by 1 per cent halothane. With this spontaneously breathing patient under anaesthesia, the breathing circuit of choice would be:
questions.solution:
Mapleson System Classification

Required fresh gas flows
Mapleson class Other names Configuration1 Spontaneous Controlled Comments
A Magill attachment Equal to minute ventilation (≈80 mL/kg/min) Very high and difficult to predict

  • Most efficient for spontaneous ventilation
  • Poor choice during controlled ventilation
B 2 × minute ventilation 2–2.5 × minute ventilation Not used in modern practice
C Water’s to-and-fro 2 × minute ventilation 2–2.5 × minute ventilation Not used in modern practice
D Bain 2–3 × minute ventilation 1–2 × minute ventilation Bain coaxial modification: fresh gas tube inside breathing tube (to warm fresh gas). Most efficient for controlled ventilation

F Jackson Rees 2–3 × minute ventilation 2 × minute ventilation A Mapleson E with a breathing bag connected to the end of the breathing tube to allow controlled ventilation and scavenging. Commonly used for pediatric patients and transportation

questions.text: A 25?year?old woman presented with pain in the left lumbar regions with increased urine frequency. Physical examination revealed a healthy female with no abnormal signs on abdominal, genitourinary, and neurologic examination. The results of blood biochemical and hematological tests were normal except for a peripheral blood eosinophil count of 759/μ L. CT of the abdomen and pelvis revealed linear calcification occupying the entire bladder wall circumference. The most probable cause is:
questions.solution:
Schistosomiasis (Bilharziasis)

  • S. hematobium - Affects bladder
  • S. japonicum - Affects liver & small intestine
  • S. mansoni - Affects large intestine

Pathology

  • Schistosoma eggs are highly antigenic and induce an intense granulomatous reaction in the bladder resulting in bladder fibrosis with ureteric or urethral strictures.
  • Calcification of dead eggs within the bladder can produce calcified bladder or bladder stones

Complications

  • Bladder calcification: Schistosomiasis is the MC cause of bladder calcification worldwide.
  • Urolithiasis, ascending urinary tract infection, urethral & ureteric stricture with subsequent hydronephrosis, & renal failure.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma (Most serious complication)

Symptoms

  • MC symptom of urinary schistosomiasis is urinary frequency.
  • Acute inflammation phase when eggs are deposited, penetrate tissues and excreted (hematuria, frequency & terminal dysuria)
  • Fever, rigor, toxemia & uremia are manifestations of renal involvement
  • Signs:−
    • In early uncomplicated cases, there are essentially no clinical findings.
    • In advanced cases, a rectal examination may reveal a fibrosed prostate, enlarged seminal vesicle, or thickened bladder base.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presented to you with the following finding as shown in the image below. Initial investigations were done. The image of the peripheral smear is given below. All of the following statements are true about the condition except?

choices.text: Piano key movement of ulnar styloid

questions.solution:
• The image shows nodules on extensor distribution along with peripheral smear showing presence of normocytic anemia. The first differential to be considered is rheumatoid arthritis.
  • The nodules are non-tender and are a late feature and hence not considered in diagnostic criteria for Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • “Piano-key movement” of the ulnar styloid occurs due to inflammation about the ulnar styloid and tenosynovitis of the extensor carpi ulnaris.
  • “Z-line deformity” is due to subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint due to damage to the tendons, joint capsule.

questions.text: A 62-year male presented with hematochezia and abdominal pain. He had lost 8 kg weight since 6 months. Blood investigations revealed moderate anemia. Colonoscopic findings included edematous mucosa with severe stenosis and obstruction of the descending colon that did not allow inserting the scope further. Barium swallow study showed Apple core appearance of intestine. Which of the following is one of the most important prognostic factors for given disease?
questions.solution:
Most important prog­nostic factors for colorectal carcinoma are:

  • Depth of invasion of tumor.
  • Presence or absence oflymph node metastasis

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:

Right to be informed
Right to choose
Right to seek redressal

Which of the above is/are the rights included in the Consumer Protection Act?
questions.solution: In India for the first time, Consumer Protection Act, 1986 provided consumers a forum for speedy redressal of their grievances against medical services. • Recently, ESI hospitals have been brought within the ambit of Consumer Protection Act. It recognizes 6 rights to the consumer: (1) Right to safety, (2) Right to be informed, (3) Right to choose, (4) Right to be heard, (5) Right to seek redressal, (6) Right to consumer education. The monitory limits of compensation that can be granted by the consumer court are as follows: 1. District consumer court - to Rs. 20 lakh 2. State commission - Rs. 20 lakh to 1 crore 3. National commission - above Rs. 1 crore.

questions.text: A reproductive age woman came with complains of lower abdominal pain, fever and dysmenorrhea. Urine pregnancy test turned negative & On serial investigations, she was diagnosed with PID. The risk factors of acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) are the following except:

choices.text: Menstruating teenagers who have multiple sex partners
Women with monogamous partner who had vasectomy

questions.solution:
Risk factors of PID

  • Menstruating teenagers.
  • Multiple sexual partners.
  • Absence of contraceptive pill use.
  • Previous history of acute PID.
  • IUD users.
  • Area with high prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases.

Protective factors of PID

Contraceptive practice

  • Barrier methods, specially condom, diaphragm with spermicides
  • Oral steroidal contraceptives have got two preventive aspects.
    • Produce thick mucus plug preventing ascent of sperm and bacterial penetration
    • Decrease in duration of menstruation, creates a shorter interval of bacterial colonization of the upper tract.
  • Monogamy or having a partner who had vasectomy.

Others

  • Pregnancy
  • Menopause
  • Vaccines: Hepatitis B, HPV

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman complains of lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting for several days. She denies sexually transmitted disease although she is sexually active but uses barrier methods for protection. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. Her blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 86/ min, and temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Abdominal examination demonstrates vague left lower quadrant tenderness without rebound or guarding. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix without cervical motion tenderness. No adnexal masses are appreciated. Blood investigations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
• In this question patient is presenting with amenorrhea of 6 weeks and she has history of being sexually active.
  • The most common cause of secondary amenorrhea is pregnancy, so first rule it out by doing a rapid urine hCG test, i.e urine pregnancy test and then do USG to see whether the pregnancy is intrauterine or extrauterine

questions.text: Bile is a fluid that is made and released by the liver and stored in the gallbladder. Bile produced in caudate lobe of the liver usually drains?

choices.text: Directly through separate ducts into gall bladder
Via both Left and Right Hepatic ducts

questions.solution:
• Caudate lobe – 1st segment – drains bile into both right and left hepatic duct.
  • Also, it has arterial supply from both right and left hepatic arteries.
  • Supplied by both right and left branches of portal vein but drain directly into IVC.

questions.text: A couple with primary infertility presents to the fertility clinic. The male partner is adviced a semen analysis and the female is adviced ovulation scans, HSG and hormonal assay. Which of the following findings in the semen characterize male factor for the couple's infertility?

questions.text: A male infant was born at 38 weeks gestation and BW of 3.42kg. Polyhydramnios was noted on antenatal scanning. On day 1 the infant had repeated episodes of vomiting in between feeds and had not passed meconium from birth. Abdominal distension was evident and following NGT placement there were bile-stained aspirates. The anus was patent. A PFA demonstrated dilated loops of bowel and a Gastrograffin study showed no flow of contrast beyond the rectosigmoid junction. The diagnosis of this case is usually associated with:
questions.solution:
Simple Meconium Ileus

  • Meconium ileus in the newborn represents the earliest clinical manifestation of Cystic fibrosis and affects roughly 15% of patients with this inherited disease.
  • In simple meconium ileus, the terminal ileum is dilated and filled with thick, tarlike, inspissated meconium.
  • Smaller pellets of meconium are found in the more distal ileum, leading into a relatively small colon.

Clinical Features

  • Present with signs and symptoms of distal intestinal obstruction

Diagnosis:

  • Abdominal X-ray in Meconium Ileus
    • Dilated, gas-filled loops of small bowel
    • Absence of air-fluid levels
    • Mass of meconium within the right side of the abdomen mixed with gas to give a ground-glass or soap bubble appearance
  • Investigation of choice: Water-soluble (Gastrografin) contrast enema.

Treatment

  • Water-soluble (Gastrografin) contrast enema is successful in relieving the obstruction in up to 75% of cases Q , with a bowel perforation rate of less than 3%.
  • Contrast agents are hypertonic relative to serum, so infants should be well hydrated and electrolytes and vital signs carefully monitored following the procedure
  • Operative management is required when the obstruction cannot be relieved with contrast enema.

questions.text: A 6-year-old malnourished HIV-seropositive boy came to the hospital for consultation. Two weeks before consultation, a small ‘boil’ had developed on his upper lip, become ulcerated, and then rapidly enlarged with the destruction of his facial tissues. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen showed extensive necrosis of all the tissue elements and mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate in the immediately viable tissue, supporting the clinical diagnosis of noma. The main organisms implicated in this condition is all except:
questions.solution:
Cancrum Oris (Noma Disease or Gangrenous Stomatitis)

  • Cancrum oris or gangrenous stomatitis, is a gangrenous disease leading to tissue destruction of the face, especially the mouth and cheek
  • Rapidly progressive, polymicrobial, opportunistic infection that occurs during periods of compromised immune function.
  • Main organisms implicated: Fusobacterium, Prevotella, and Borrelia vincentii Predisposing Factors
  • Malnutrition or dehydration
  • Poor oral hygiene
  • Poor sanitation
  • Unsafe drinking water
  • Recent illness
  • Malignancy
  • Immunodeficiency disorder (AIDS)

Clinical Features

  • Mainly affects children <12 years in the poorest countries of Africa
  • Most children are between 2 and 6 years
  • Mucous membranes of the mouth develop ulcers
  • Rapid, painless tissue degeneration, can degrade tissues of the bones in the face.
  • Associated with high morbidity and mortality

Treatment

  • Improvement in hygiene and nutrition
  • Progression can be halted by antibiotics and improved nutrition
  • Reconstructive plastic surgery Q to repair its permanent physical effects

questions.text: An AIDS patient came with complaints of pain & redness in the eye associated with blurred vision and sensitivity to light or glare. Fundus examination of the patient is shown below and the finding is typically caused by:
questions.solution:
The fundoscopic image depicts left eye withHaemorrhagic retinitis mainly in the superior arcadeclassic form in AIDS patient caused byCMV retinitis.

Cytomegalovirus

  • It may cause disseminated disease, although, more commonly, it affects theeye and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Chorioretinitis was seen in approximately 25% of patients before the advent of HAART, but this has decreased dramatically after the initiation of HAART.
  • Cytomegalovirus retinitis occurs almostexclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.

Cryptococcosis

  • Meningitis is the major clinical manifestation of cryptococcosis

Toxoplasma gondii

  • It causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.

questions.text: India contributes to one-fifth of global live births and more than a quarter of neonatal deaths. Nearly, 0.75 million neonates died in India in 2013, the highest for any country in the world. The most common cause of having this much neonatal mortality in India is?
questions.solution:
• Preterm birth and its complications account for 35% of all neonatal deaths and constitute the most important cause of neonatal mortality
  • This is followed by neonatal sepsis (33%), birth asphyxia (20%) and congenital malformations (9%)

questions.text: You were sitting in an anatomy lecture, a question flashed on the screen “The stability of the joint depends on which of the following factors except”?

choices.text: Tone of muscles around the joint

questions.solution:
The stability of a joint depends on three main factors:

  • The morphology of the bony articular surfaces,
  • The ligaments,
  • The tone of the muscles around the joint

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with no past medical history presented to a primary stroke center with sudden left-sided weakness and imbalance followed by decreased level of consciousness. If a Non-contrast CT scan was taken in this patient all of the followings signs of acute infarct can be seen except:
questions.solution:
Signs of acute infarct:

  1. Hyperdense MCA sign
  2. Insular ribbon sign
  3. Sylvian dot sign
  4. Obscuration of lentiform nucleus

Dural tail sign

  • occurs as a result of thickening and enhancement of the dura and is most often seen adjacent to a meningioma.
  • Initially, the sign was felt to be pathognomonic of meningiomas, however as radiologist's experience grew, it has become increasingly noted to be present in many other conditions

questions.text: Scientists are having a study on the changes coming in kidney blood flow and glomerular filtration. From the study, they came to a conclusion that one of the properties can reduce the renal plasma flow and elevate the filtration fraction. Which of the following property can produce the given effect?
questions.solution:
• Efferent arteriole which is the outgoing artery, if it gets constricted, it will be preventing the blood flow through the kidney.
  • This can lead to the decrease in the renal plasma flow. But here there will be an increase in the hydrostatic pressure of glomerular capillary.
  • This happen due to the backing up by the fluids.
  • Increase in the glomerular hydrostatic pressure or the bowman’s capsule oncotic pressure will lead to increase the GFR.
  • While increase in the capillary oncotic pressure and bowman’s space hydrostatic pressure will decrease GFR.
  • Filtration fraction can be calculated by dividing the GFR by Renal plasma flow.

Option A; Bowman’s space hydrostatic pressure can be increased due to the obstruction in the neck of the bladder which will result in the decrease of the GFR. There will be no effect in the RPF. Obstruction in the neck of bladder can have effect on the filtration fraction which will be decreased due to the decrease in the GFR.

Option B; This can cause a decrease in the hydrostatic pressure of glomerular capillaries which can lead to a decrease in the GFR.

Option C; Constriction of afferent artery which is coming inside, it can cause a decrease in the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries which will result in a decreased GFR. There will be a resultant decrease in the renal plasma flow also. The filtration fraction will be remaining unchanged.

questions.text: Haem is an important component of many proteins and enzymes and its synthesis occurs in all cells of the body. However, majority of synthesis occurs in liver and erythroid tissues. Rate limiting enzyme of Haem synthesis in erythroid tissue is:
questions.solution:
• RLE in Haem Synthesis is – ALA Synthase
  • ALA Synthase I: Expressed throughout the body. (Rate-limiting step in liver)
  • ALA Synthase II: Expressed in erythroid tissues

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in Ophthalmology unit. A resident doctor is performing a procedure as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements are true about this procedure?


Useful in the classification of glaucoma
Can be performed under mydriasis
Localization of foreign bodies can be done
Demonstration of peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) extent can be done
Useful in visualizing structures posterior to iris
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is Gonioscopy.

Applications of gonioscopy:

  1. Classification of glaucoma into open angle and closed angle based on configuration of the angle.
  2. Localization of foreign bodies, abnormal blood vessels or tumours in the angle.
  3. Demonstration of peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) extent and hence planning of glaucoma surgery.
  4. Surgical aid direct goniolens is used during goniotomy

questions.text: An 87-year-old north Indian man with a symptomatic Crawford type I thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm was treated successfully with a long tube stent graft using endovascular techniques. After doing a graft repair, the patients developed weakness. Most probable cause for this:

choices.text: Decreased blood supply to the lower limbs

questions.solution:
Arteria Radicularis Magna

  • Arteria radicularis magna (artery of Adamkiewicz) is the main source of blood supply to the anterior spinal artery in the thoracolumbar segment of the spinal cord.
  • It arises from either one of the lower posterior intercostal arteries (T9-T11) or of the subcostal artery (T12), or less frequently of the upper lumbar arteries (L1 and L2).
  • Occlusion or interruption is one of the major reasons for spinal cord ischemia (leading to paraparesis /paraplegia) during surgery for thoracoabdominal aneurysms.

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida at 11 weeks of gestational age has a blood pressure reading of 150/100 mm Hg obtained during a routine visit. . The patient denies any headache, visual changes, nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. Her repeat BP is 160/90 mm Hg, and urinalysis is negative for protein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chronic hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 mmHg before pregnancy or diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or hypertension first diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and persistent after 12 weeks postpartum.

The average prevalence of hypertension in women aged 18 to 39 years is approximately 5-7 percent.

questions.text: A male child was brought by his mother for a routine check-up to the PHC as a pediatrician made a special visit that day. The mother reported that the child's birth weight was 2500gm and was delivered via normal vaginal delivery. On weighing the child, he had a weight of 10 kg. What is the probable age of the child:
questions.solution:
Age Approx. expected weight
5 – 6 months 2 × birth weight
1 year 3 × birth weight
2 years 4 × birth weight
3 years 5 × birth weight

questions.text: 60 years old male came to the hospital with signs & symptoms of right-sided heart failure. On assessing the JVP, ‘Y’ descent noted. 'Y' descent in the JVP is due to?
questions.solution: • “y” wave indicates fall of right atrial pressure due to opening of tricuspid valve leading to the ventricular filling.

questions.text:
The myoglobin content is greatest in muscles specialized for sustained contraction. Which of the following is true about myoglobin?

Myoglobin binds to 4 moles of O2 per moles
Myoglobin- O2 dissociation curve has a parabolic profile
Myoglobin has a high O2 affinity compared to hemoglobin
Myoglobin-O2 dissociation curve shows Bohr’s effect
Myoglobin-O2 dissociation curve has a hyperbolic profile
questions.solution:
Myoglobin

  • 1 molecule of myoglobin can bind with only 1 molecule of O2 (1 Hb → 4 O2).
  • However, it has a much higher O2 affinity than Hb.
  • Myoglobin-O2 dissociation curve is a rectangular hyperbola.
  • Myoglobin keeps its O2 bound even at low intracellular pO2; O2 is released by it at very low intracellular pO2 resulting from exercise. p50 for myoglobin is 5-7 mm Hg
  • The unimolecular myoglobin does not exhibit Bohr’s effect. In Bohr’s effect, O2 affinity of Hb decreases when PCO2 increases. In the muscle, O2 unloading by Hb will not be impaired due to the fact that O2 affinity of myoglobin is not decreased, as in Bohr’s effect for Hb.

questions.text: A 52-year-old postmenopausal patient has evidence of low bone mineral density. She and her physician are considering therapy with raloxifene or a combination of conjugated estrogens and medroxyprogesterone acetate. Which of the following patient characteristics is MOST likely to lead them to select raloxifene?

choices.text: Strong family history of breast cancer

questions.solution:
• Raloxifene is a SERM used in post-menopausal osteoporosis due to its agonist action in bone.
  • It has additional advantage of causing decrease in risk of breast and endometrial cancer due to its estrogen antagonists’ action at these places.
  • Major adverse effect of raloxifene isthromboembolismandaggravation of hot flushes of menopause.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with a clinical finding as shown in the image below. Histopathological examination of the lesion showed well differentiated tumor with characteristic keratin pearls and intercellular bridges. Which of the following statement is incorrect about the diagnosis?

choices.text: It is the most common malignancy of eyelid
Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
The tumor invades the stroma deeply
Surgical excision is the treatment of choice
Topical chemotherapy with mitomycin is useful to decrease recurrence

questions.solution:
• The above clinical picture & features are suggestive of Squamous cell carcinoma of eyelid.
  • It is the second most common malignancy of eyelid.
  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common malignancy of eyelid.

Squamous cell carcinoma (epithelioma):

  • It usually occurs at the transitional zones, i.e. at limbus and the lid margin.
  • The tumour invades the stroma deeply and may be fixed to underlying tissues

Risk factors include:

  • Exposure to intense UV radiation,
  • Advanced age,
  • Cigarette smoking,
  • AIDS and conjunctiva [ human papilloma virus (HPV) infections,
  • History of squamous cell carcinoma in head and neck,
  • Xeroderma pigmentosa, and
  • Light complexion.

Treatment: Surgical excision with surrounding 2-4 mm of normal tissue is the treatment of choice. Measures to decrease recurrence include:

  • Cryotherapy to surrounding tissue,
  • Topical chemotherapy with mitomycin.

Radical excision including enucleation and even exenteration may be needed along with postoperative radiotherapy in advanced cases of SCC.

questions.text: 40 years old male came to the hospital with complaints of pallor, headache and fever not reaching the normal baseline. On examination, (+) edema over the mastoid surface. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sigmoid/lateral sinus thrombosis

C/F- pallor

  • headache
  • picket fence fever- temperature does not come to normal baseline

GRIESINGER’S SIGN:

Griesinger’s sign is mastoid tenderness and oedema secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emmisary vein.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male with colorectal cancer metastasized to liver (Segment VII), came into your hepatic clinic on referral. You inform the onco-surgeon that since the metastasis is extensive, it may require hepatectomy. Which of the following group of vessels can be embolized to form collaterals, given that they drain deoxygenated blood from the liver into the IVC?
questions.solution:
• The upper group (right, left, and middle) and lower group (variable numbers) of hepatic veins open in vena cava as venous drainage of liver.
  • There is literature suggesting that Hepatic vein embolization, helps in establishment of venous collateral between lobes of liver, in cases of hepatectomies where vasculature was removed.
  • Portal vein carry venous blood of gut to liver
  • Superior mesenteric vein and splenic vein will form Portal vein.

questions.text:
Which of the following are morphological features of childhood polycystic kidney disease?

Enlarged kidney with smooth external surface
Dilated elongated channels present at right angle to the cortical surface
Cysts are lined by cuboidal cells
Cut section- Sponge like appearance

choices.text: All are features of childhood polycystic disease

questions.solution:
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD)/Childhood polycystic kidney disease

  • Kidneys - Enlarged,smooth externalappearance.
  • Cut section, numerous small cysts give kidney a"sponge-like" appearance.
  • Dilatedelongated channels are present at right angles to the cortical surface, completely replacing the medulla and cortex.
  • M/E -Cylindricalor, less commonly,sacculardilation of all collecting tubules.
  • The cysts have a uniform lining ofcuboidalcells.

questions.text: Amino acids are divided into various categories based on their chemical structure, polarity and essentially for the body. Non-essential amino acid group is?
questions.solution:
• All the Acidic amino acids (Aspartate, Glutamate) are non-essential i.e. they can be synthesized from TCA intermediates.
  • All the Acidic amino acids (Aspartate, Glutamate) are non-essential i.e. they can be synthesized from TCA intermediates.
  • All branched-chain amino acids are essential.
  • Most aromatic amino acids are essential.

questions.text:
Given below are the statements 1,2,3, regarding "Levels of prevention":

Risk factor modification is under primordial level
Rehabilitation is under tertiary level of prevention
Reconstructive surgery for leprosy patients is under secondary level of prevention
questions.solution:
Q. What it prevents?

  • Primordial: Risk factor
  • Primary: Disease
  • Secondary: Complication
  • Tertiary: Further Complication
  • Quaternary: Over Diagnosis
  1. Risk factor modification is under primordial level - primary
  2. Rehabilitation is under tertiary level of prevention - correct
  3. Reconstructive surgery for leprosy patients is under secondary level of prevention - tertiary

questions.text: A PSM intern was posted in a rural PHC. In morning OPD session the senior physician asked him to explain about Primary health care center. All of the following are incorrect statements regarding PHC except?

choices.text: Staff of PHC must have a radiographer
PHC with ≥ 10 deliveries per month is categorized as type B PHC
1 PHC is established per 5000 population in hilly areas
Provision of total beds at PHC is 4-6

questions.solution:
PHC

  • Population:
    • 30000 population (Plains)
    • 20000 population (Hilly/tribal areas)
  • Staff
    • Pharmacist
    • Lab technician
    • Multi-skilled group D worker
  • Type
    • Type A PHC: PHC with< 20deliveries per month
    • Type B PHC: PHC with≥ 20deliveries per month
  • Provision of total beds at PHC is 4-6

questions.text: The cause of death of the 30-year-old IT employee, who was found dead in her apartment, was confirmed to be due to asphyxia. Further investigations have been initiated to determine the method employed by the killer to cause suffocation. Any of the following acts can lead to suffocation except?
questions.solution:
Throttling is a form of manual strangulation, not a form of suffocation.

Suffocation deaths:

SmotheringQ Occlusion ofexternal air passagesQby hand, pillow, plastic bag etc
ChokingQ Occlusion ofinternal air passagesQby foreign body, food particles etc
Overlaying Compression of chestQ, when mother shares bed with baby
GaggingQ Occlusion ofinternal air passages at pharyngeal level by a gagQ
BurkingQ Smothering and traumatic asphyxia

questions.text: You are called to a maternity ward to see a 23 year old primi patient who had delivered a 2.8 kg baby boy 3 days back.She had a normal vaginal delivery and placenta delivered spontaneously. Now she complains of bloody vaginal discharge with no other signs. O/E you notice a sweetish odour bloody discharge on the vaginal walls and introitus.Sterile pelvic examination shoes a soft non tender uterus.Her P/R-80/min, BP-110/70 mm of hg, temp-37°C, RR-16/min. Her WBC count =10,000 with predominant granulocytes. What is the most appropriate step?
questions.solution:
• Patient is a puerperal female who is complaining of bloody vaginal discharge with no other significant abnormal signs.
  • On examination there is a sweetish odour bloody discharge on the vaginal walls and introitus. Her vitals are normal suggesting that this cannot be PPH (The most common cause of secondary PPH is retained bits of placenta for which curettage is done, but here it is not required).
  • Slight amount of bloody discharge called as lochia is absolutely normal for the first 15 days after delivery and doesnot require any treatment, so we will reassure the patient and do nothing.
  • Donot get confused with the finding of WBC count, 10,000 with predominant granulocytes as this is a normal finding in the puerperal period Note- leucocytes can rise to as high as 25000 during puerperium probably as a response to the stress of labor).
  • Since lochia has no foul smell it means no infection and so no need for culture or antibiotics.

questions.text: A 35 yr old male patient complains of loss of appetite, abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss for past 6 months. Investigations done which revealed abnormal schilling test. Antibiotics were given for 5 days which results in normalization of schilling test. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
• Schilling test helps in determining etiology of vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Bacterial overgrowth syndrome occurs due to growth of large intestinal microbiota flora like bacteroides to multiply in small intestine.
  • Hence after a course of antibiotics when the flora will die, normal B12 absorption can take place and schilling test will become normal.
  • In chronic pancreatitis, test will become normal with addition of pancreatic supplements.
  • In atrophic gastritis, IF supplementation will normalize the schilling test.
  • If in spite of antibiotics, IF supplementation and pancreatic enzymes the test remains abnormal, it indicates presence of ileal mucosal disease.

questions.text: Cardiac dominance plays an essential role in cardiac surgery, particularly coronary artery bypass grafting. It is determined by the coronary artery supplying?

choices.text: Supplying circulation to the SA node
Supplying circulation to the inferior portion of the interventricular septum
Supplying circulation to the interatrial septum
Supplying circulation to the anterior portion of the interventricular septum

questions.solution:
• Cardiac dominance is determined by posterior interventricular artery (PIVA) which supplies posteroinferior part of interventricular septum.
  • Mostly this a branch of Right Coronary Artery so right cardiac dominance (65% of population)
  • If posterior interventricular artery arise from left coronary artery, then it is left cardiac dominance in 10% of population (bad prognosis)
  • Multiple PIVA one from right side one from left side that is codominance in 25% of population.

questions.text: All of the following are deformities present in the condition shown in the image except:

choices.text: Eversion of foot at Talocalcaneal joint
Excessive arching of the foot at mid-tarsal joints

questions.solution:
• Idiopathic deformity of the foot of unclear etiology
  • Epidemiology
    • demographics
      • most common musculoskeletal birth defect
      • overall incidence 1:1,000, though some populations 1:250
      • highest prevalence in Hawaiians and Maoris
      • male:female ratio approximately 2:1
  • location ??- half of cases are bilateral
    • In 80%, clubfoot is an isolated deformity
  • Deformities consist of the following elements
    • CAVUS : Exaggerated Medial Longitudinal arch at midfoot
    • ADDUCTION : Forefoot in adduction in tarsometatarsal junction
    • VARUS : Hind foot rotated inward at talocalcaneonavicular joint
    • EQUINUS : Foot fixed in plantar flexion at ankle joint

questions.text: A 55-year-old male smoker plumber by occupation presented with complaints of dyspnea, chronic cough. CT thorax showed bilateral pleural plaques at the basal areas of lungs, fibrotic changes. Transbronchial biopsies showed finding as shown in the image. What is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image is showing Ferruginous bodies which are seen inasbestosis.

Ferruginous body/ Asbestos bodyappears as a yellow, beaded structures with clubbed ends. proteinaceous material with iron.

Asbestos exposure is a well-known risk factor for the development of mesothelioma.

At risk are people working in plumbing and insulation.

Most commonly involves base of the lung.

questions.text:
Mark the correct answers regarding premature closure of sutures






Dolichocephaly
Brachycephaly
Asymetrical brachycephaly
Trigonocephaly
Plagiocephaly
Scaphocephaly
questions.solution:
• The most common form of craniosynostosis is premature closure of the sagittal suture, giving a scaphocephalic (boat-shaped) or dolichocephalic head.
  • Premature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, either major/minor, is called CRANIOSYNOSTOSIS.
  • Forms of craniosynostosis
    • Trigonocephaly - Metopic suture
    • Brachycephaly - Bilateral coronal sutures
    • Left anterior plagiocephaly - Left coronal suture
    • Right anterior plagiocephaly - Right coronal suture
    • Scaphocephaly - Sagittal suture
    • Right posterior plagiocephaly - Right lambdoid suture
    • Left posterior plagiocephaly - Left lambdoid suture
    • Cloverleaf skull deformity - Caused by fusion of multiple sutures; associated with hydrocephalus
    • Tower skull or acrocephaly - Combined sagittal, coronal, and lambdoid synostosis, often as part of Apert or Crouzon syndrome

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustained a significant blunt trauma to his right eye while playing tennis. X-ray finding revealed fragmentation and irregularity of the orbital floor on the right side. Which of the following features is not usually expected in such patients?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history & findings are suggestive of Blow-out fracture of the right eye. *Bilateral epistaxis is usually not expected in patients with blow-out fracture. Ipsilateral epistaxis can be seen.

Clinical features of Blow-out fracture/orbital floor fracture:

  1. Periorbital oedema and blood extravasation in and around the orbit (such as subconjunctival ecchymosis) occur immediately. This may mask certain signs and symptoms seen later.
  2. Emphysema of the eyelids occurs more frequently with medial wall than floor fractures. It may be made worse by blowing of the nose.
  3. Paraesthesia and anaesthesia in the distribution of infraorbital nerve (lower lid, cheek, side of nose, upper lip and upper teeth) arc vc1y common.
  4. Ipsilateral epistaxis as a result of bleeding from maxillary sinus into the nose is frequently noted in early stages.
  5. Proptosis, of variable degree, may also be present initially because of the associated orbital oedema and haemorrhage.
  6. Enophthalmos and mechanical ptosis. After about 10 days, as the oedema decreases, the eyeball sinks backward and somewhat inferiorly resulting in enophthalmos and mechanical ptosis. Three factors responsible for producing enophthalmos are:
  • Escape of orbital fat into the maxillary sinus;
  • Backward traction on the globe by entrapped inferior rectus muscle; and
  • Enlargement of the orbital cavity from displacement of fragments.

7. Diplopia also becomes evident after the decrease in oedema. It typically occurs in both up and down gaze (double diplopia) due to entrapment of soft tissue structures in the area of the blowout fracture. The presence of muscle restriction can be confirmed by a positive forced duction test.' 8. Severe ocular damage, associated with blow-out fracture, is rare. This is because a 'blow-out fracture' is nature's way of protecting the globe from injury. Nevertheless, the eye should be carefully examined to exclude the possibility of intraocular damage.

questions.text: A 15 yr old girl presented with dysmenorrhea in every menstrual period. Menarche occurs at 13 yrs of age. Since then she experiences this very severe pain at right side associated with nausea and vomiting. She cant attend the school during menses from past year for which she consulted and started to take NSAIDs. Initially it is effective but after sometime it is ineffective. What is next line of management?

choices.text: High dose of non specific steroid

questions.solution:
• Dysmenorrhea is cyclic pain with menstruation and accompanies most menses.
  • This pain is classically described as cramping and is often accompanied by low backache, nausea and vomiting, headache or diarrhea.
  • Primary dysmenorrhea describes cyclical menstrual pain without an identifiable associated pathology.
  • Secondary dysmenorrhea is cyclical menstrual pain which may frequently complicates endometriosis, leiomyomas, PID, adenomyosis, endometrial polyps, and menstrual outlet obstruction.
  • Given case scenario, the patient suffers from chronic pelvic pain secondary to dysmenorrhea.
  • First line drug for dysmenorrhea is NSAIDS
  • If it doesnot relieve symptoms further workup should be done to rule out other pathologies.
  • So the next best choice is to do PELVIC & ABDOMINAL USG

questions.text: Earliest light microscopic change in myocardial infarction is shown in image. Identify:
questions.solution:
• When there is depletion of ATP, there is development of swelling in Myofibers leading to the haphazard arrangement of fibres causing waviness of the fibers.
  • The typical changes of coagulative necrosis become detectable in the first 6 to 12 hours.
  • “Wavy Fibers” may be present at the periphery of the infarct.
  • These changes probably result from the forceful systolic tugs of the viable fibers on immediately adjacent, noncontractile dead fibers, causing stretching and folding.

questions.text: A patient presented in medicine emergency on stretcher. On examination his BP was found to be 80/50, his relatives also told that he was going for urination very infrequently. The doctor prescribed a medicine to the patient. What was the medicine and what is its dose in this case?
questions.solution:
Dopamine acts on D1R at a concentration of <2mcg/Kg/min and has maximum action in renal blood vessels, producing vasodilation which helps in oliguria.

Dopamine acts on beta 1R at a concentration of 2-10mcg/Kg/min and it acts on the heart (used in cases of CHF).

Dopamine, in concentrations of >10mcg/Kg/min, acts on α1R, producing vasoconstriction which helps in shock and oliguria.

Hence, it is the DOC FOR SHOCK WITH OLIGURIA.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ED complaining of chest pain and drooling that started immediately after eating a chicken steak. His past medical history is significant for ingestion of a caustic solution, 5 years ago. On physical examination, the patient can talk normally and breathe without effort. The chest pain is vague and constant. A chest X-ray shows no subcutaneous emphysema. An endoscopy confirms the presence of a retained bolus of meat 25 cm beyond the incisors where a stricture is identified. Which of the following anatomic spaces contains the stricture?
questions.solution:
• The aortic arch leaves an imprint in the right anterior edge of the esophagus in the superior mediastinum at about 23 (±3 cm) beyond the upper incisors.
  • This is the 2nd most common location of injury and stricture formation.

Option 1:

  • The esophagus is compressed by the left main bronchus in the posterior mediastinum.
  • Although this area can also be damaged from caustic ingestions, it resides lower down, at 30 cm beyond the incisors.

Option 3:

  • The anterior mediastinum, limited laterally by the pleura, posteriorly by the pericardium, anteriorly by the sternum, the left transversus thoracis muscle, and the fifth, sixth, and seventh left costal cartilages, contains only the superior and inferior Sterno-pericardial ligaments and remnants of the thymus.
  • These structures do not come into contact with the esophagus.

Option 4:

  • The abdominal portion of the esophagus is variable in length (0.5–2.5 cm).
  • The junction of the esophagus and the stomach lies inferior to the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm.
  • The phreno-esophageal ligament anchors the esophagogastric junction to allow movement with respiration but to prevent significant (more than 1–2 cm) proximal movement of the superior margin of the stomach.

questions.text: A paramedical staff working at a semen bank uses a chemical for preservation of semen samples. The role of this agent is to prevent formation of ice crystals when semen is frozen to extremely low temperatures. The agent used commonly is:
questions.solution:
Preservation of semen:

  • The most common cryoprotectant used for semen is glycerol (10% in culture medium).
  • Cryoprotectant media may be supplemented with either egg yolk or soy lecithin
  • Liquid Nitrogen is the medium in which these 'Cassettes' containing' sperms and cryoprotectants' are stored in.
  • Cryopreservation of sperms,ova and embryos is one big step in the field of infertility.
  • It avoids repeated aspiration.
  • It also permits donation of eggs as well as of sperms to couples whose husband is azoospermic or wife is in capable of ovulation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who had given birth to a first child in the primary healthcare facility was taken by her family to the Psychiatry with complaints of lack of energy, fatigue, lack of concentration and awareness, gloomy and pessimistic future vision, sleep disturbances, loss of appetite. On questioning the patient she said that she has no will to live and wants to end her life. The probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Postpartum depression

  • DSM- 5: Depressive episode with peripartum onset
  • More severe depressive symptoms seen in 10-15% in the first 3 months of delivery
  • Sadness, tearfulness, lability, sleep disturbances
  • Anhedonia
  • Suicidal thoughts /thought of harming baby/guilt
  • History of mood disorder
  • Family h/o mood disorders
  • Increased risk of future depressive episodes
  • Treatment-Pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy
  • In 2019, FDA approved Brexanolone (continuous i.v. infusion for 60 hours)- it is similar to endogenous allopregnanolone- which is a hormone that decreases after childbirth.

Postpartum blues/Baby blues: This reaction results from psychological factors (e.g., the emotional stress of childbirth, the feelings o added responsibility) as well as physiological factors (e.g., changes in hormone levels, fatigue).

  • Experienced by 30-75% of female
  • Transient symptoms like tearfulness; sadness, mood lability, sleep disturbances
  • Onset 3rd-day peak by 5th day
  • Resolves by 7 - 10th day.
  • Support to mother is enough

Postpartum psychosis

  • Within 2-3 weeks
  • Initial- tearfulness, insomnia, lability
  • Delusion & hallucinations (baby is dead, she didn’t give birth)
  • Risk of harm to self or baby
  • Episode of bipolar disorder
  • Mostly recovery is complete
  • 2/3rd patients have another episode in next 1 year
  • Rx- antipsychotics + Li+ + antidepressants

HOW TO REMEMBER: Blues = no one is hurt; depression = patient is hurt; psychosis = others are hurt because of the patient (baby is harmed)

A patient presented with bulging right eye with restriction of right eye movements. On examination, the corneal sensations were also found to be decreased. The left eye had no bulging but there was limitation of abduction in left eye. What is the likely scenario?
questions.solution:
The most likely event is that the right orbit was first involved, which gradually progressed to cavernous sinus, and the pathology crossed to left side and involved 6th nerve of left cavernous sinus.

Superior orbital fissure syndrome and Orbital apex syndrome are unilateral, and does not involve the other eye. Pseudotumor is an inflammatory condition of orbit, but corneal sensations are not decreased.

questions.text: Electron microscopy findings of renal biopsy show permeation of the lamina densa of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) by a ribbon-like, homogeneous, extremely electron-dense material of unknown composition. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dense-deposit disease(formerly called TypeII MPGN)

  • Excessive activation of thealternative complement pathway.
  • Electron M/E - Permeation of thelamina densaof the GBM by a ribbon-like, homogeneous, extremely electron-dense material of the unknown composition.
  • By immunofluorescence,C3 is present in irregular granular or linear foci in the basement membraneson either side but not within the dense deposits.
  • C3 is also present in the mesangium in characteristic circular aggregates (mesangial rings).
  • IgG is usually absent, as are components of the classical pathway of complement activation (such as C1q and C4).

questions.text: A 63-year-old male complained of malaise, nausea, vomiting, weakness, fatigue, urine volume reduction (about 600 ml/24 h), and deteriorating dyspnea. Laboratory investigation revealed renal insufficiency (serum creatinine Cr:2 mg/ dl). An intravenous pyelography had been performed using an inexplicably large dose of contrast medium. IVP had shown no signs of lithiasis or obstruction. The patient left the clinic two days after the pyelography. The renal function had been reevaluated after 3 days of administration of the contrast medium which showed a serum creatinine level of 7.8 mg/dL suggesting Contrast-induced nephropathy. The contrast material that is least likely responsible for the condition in this patient would be:
questions.solution:
Contrast Agents with High Iodine: particle ratio tends to be less nephrotoxic

Iodixanol is an Isoosmolar contrast agent, Nonionic Dimer with Iodine: Particle Ratio of 6:1 and tends to be less nephrotoxic than the other iodinated compounds given here

Contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN)

  • Classically defined as a serum creatinine increase of at least 25% or an absolute increase in serum creatinine of 0.5mg/dL after using iodine contrast agent without another clear cause for acute kidney injury within 48-72hrs of Intravenous contrast
  • Markers of CIN
    • Serum Cystatin C levels
    • Neutrophil Gelatinase associated lipocalcin (NAGL)
    • eGFR<60ml/min
  • For prevention- Maintain Hydration

questions.text: If the angle shown in the image is decreased, the probable bone fractured would be:
questions.solution:
Böhler angle, also written as Bohler angle or Boehler angle, is also called the calcaneal angle or tuber joint angle.

Measurement

Böhler angle is the angle between two lines tangent to the calcaneus on the lateral radiograph. These lines are drawn tangent to the anterior and posterior aspects of the superior calcaneus.

Interpretation

The "normal" value for this angle is between 20° to 40°. A value <20° can be seen in calcaneal fractures. However, a mildly decreased Böhler angle may be seen in a normal individual 5 and a normal Böhler angle does not exclude a calcaneal fracture.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female tourist to India presents with diffuse chest pain. There is no past history of heart disease, hypertension, and diabetes. She is admitted for observation and next morning she has a recurrence of chest pain and ECG shows ST elevation in V1 to V4. Troponin is normal and pain is promptly relieved by sublingual NTG. Which of the following is the best management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Exercise stress testing and long-acting nitrates
Coronary angiography with long-acting nitrates and CCB

questions.solution:
CORONARY VASOSPASM & ANGINA WITH NORMAL CORONARY ARTERIOGRAMS

ESSENTIALS OF DIAGNOSIS

  • Precordial chest pain, often occurring at rest during stress or without known precipitant, relieved rapidly by nitrates.
  • ECG evidence of ischemia during pain, sometimes with ST-segment elevation.
  • Angiographic demonstration of: – No significant obstruction of major coronary vessels.
  • Coronary spasm that responds to intracoronary nitroglycerin or calcium channel blockers.

Clinical Findings

  • Ischemia may be silent or result in angina pectoris.
  • Prinzmetal (variant) angina is a clinical syndrome in which chest pain occurs without the usual precipitating factors and is associated with ST-segment elevation rather than depression.
  • It often affects women under 50 years of age. It characteristically occurs in the early morning, awakening patients from sleep, and is apt to be associated with arrhythmias or conduction defects.
  • It may be diagnosed by challenge with ergonovine (a vasoconstrictor), although the results of such provocation are not specific and it entails risk.

Treatment

Patients with chest pain associated with ST-segment elevation should undergo coronary arteriography to determine whether fixed stenotic lesions are present. If they are, aggressive medical therapy or revascularization is indicated, since this may represent an unstable phase of the disease.

If significant lesions are not seen and spasm is suspected, avoidance of precipitants, such as cigarette smoking and cocaine, is the top priority.

  1. Nitrate and calcium channel blockers are the main therapeutic agents.
  2. Asprin:Aspirin may actually increase the severity of ischemic episodes, possibly as a result of the sensitivity of coronary tone to modest changes in the synthesis of prostacyclin.
  3. Statin therapy has been shown to reduce the risk of major adverse events, although the precise mechanism is not established. The response to beta blockers is variable.
  4. Coronary revascularisation:Coronary revascularization may be helpful in patients who also have discrete, flow-limiting, proximal fixed obstructive lesions.
  5. ICD:Patients who have had ischemia-associated ventricular fibrillation despite maximal medical therapy should receive an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

Choice 2 and 4 are done for chronic stable angina

Choice 1 will offers no diagnostic help.

questions.text: A 34 yr old female, known HIV patient now presents with severe headache and Nuchal stiffness. Lumbar puncture was done which revealed clear CSF with leucocytes >100/cu.mm. India ink staining was positive. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• C. neoformans is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS.
  • It is the initial AIDS defining illness in <2% of patients and generally occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <100/microlitres.
  • Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs.
  • CSF profile may be normal or may show only modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and decrease in glucose. Opening pressure in CSF is usually elevated.
  • Diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of organism in spinal fluid with india ink examination or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen.
  • Blood culture for fungus are often positive. A biopsy may be needed to make a diagnosis of CNS crytococcoma. '
  • Treatment is with IV Amphotericin B 0.7mg/kg daily or liposomal amphotericin 4 to 6 mg/kg daily, with flucytosine 25 mg/kg qid for atleast 2 weeks and if possible until CSF culture turns negative.followed by Fluconazole 400mg/d PO for 8 weeks and the fluconazole 200mg/day until the CD 4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/microlitre for 6 months in response to cART.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient was sent to the emergency department by ambulance because of a motorcycle crash on the way home. On examination, both the limbs of the patient were severely injured. Limb salvage can be considered in all except:
questions.solution:
Bailey says “Amputation should be considered when part of a limb is dead, deadly or a dead loss. A limb is dead when the arterial occlusive disease is severe enough to cause infarction of macroscopic portions of tissue, i.e. gangrene. The occlusion may be in major vessels (atherosclerotic or embolic occlusions) or in small peripheral vessels (diabetes, Buerger’s disease, Raynaud’s disease, inadvertent intra-arterial injection). If the obstruction cannot be reversed and the symptoms are severe, amputation is required.”

Indications for Amputation

Dead limb Deadly limb ‘Dead loss’ limb
  • Gangrene
  • Wet gangrene
  • Spreading cellulitis
  • Arteriovenous fistula
  • Other (e.g. malignancy)
  • Severe rest pain
  • Paralysis
  • Other (e.g. contracture, trauma)

  2. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia of late onset

This cannot be Sertoli cell Tumor as there are no sign of virilization (e.g. clitoromegaly), there is only hirsutism.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true about proportional case rate of malaria?

This indicator is used since morbidity rate is difficult to determine
This is defined as the number of cases of malaria for every 100 patients seen in hospital OPDs
It is a crude index since cases are not related to their time and space distribution

Select the Answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Parasite rate: Percentage of children between the age of 2 and 10 years showing malaria parasite in their blood film Proportional case rate: Number of cases diagnosed as clinical malaria for every 100 patient attending the hospital and dispensaries. It is a crude index because cases are not related to their time and space distribution.

Because morbidity rate is difficult to determine except in condition where diagnosis and case reporting is carried to perfection, proportional rate is used.

Pain may refer to the shoulder or upper arm
Most commonly associated with tubercular salpingitis
