Fitz-Hugh–Curtis syndrome:-

  • A woman with PID complains of Acute right-sided upper abdominal pain simulating Cholecystitis.
  • This is due to a fibrous band extending from the Right adnexa to the under surface of the Liver in PID caused by Gonococcal and Chlamydial infection.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with an episode of syncopal ventricular tachycardia secondary to arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia. A dual-chamber implantable cardiac defibrillator (ICD) was implanted without complication. Six months later, an increase in the device’s lead impedance was detected on routine pacemaker checks. The best method to investigate an implantable cardioverter Defibrillator is:
questions.solution:
Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) is an electronic device with a defibrillator unit capable of generating and delivering an electrical impulse and shock to abort dysrhythmias and return the heart to sinus rhythm. ICDs can be either transvenous (T-ICD) or subcutaneous (S-ICD). T-ICDs contain a lead with either one or two metal shock coils placed at the brachiocephalic vein/superior vena cava junction and the RV

Chest radiography is the preferred imaging modality to evaluate ICD's anatomic location, lead wire integrity, and help in identifying several complications.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male presented with left upper quadrant abdominal pain of 2 days duration. The pain was constant, sharp, radiated to the back, and was aggravated on movement and relieved by rest. The past medical history was significant for fatty liver and had a history of smoking and alcohol abuse. On examination, the finding shown in the image was seen. The ideal fluid of choice for this patient would be:
questions.solution:
From the given data and the image showing Cullen’s sign, a diagnosis of Acute pancreatitis can be made.

Acute pancreatitis

  • Rapidly progressive inflammatory response associated with prolonged length of hospital stay and significant morbidity & mortality occur in 10-20% Q of patients
  • Mortality rate: Mild pancreatitis <1%; Severe pancreatitis 10-30% Q .

Clinical Features

  • Cardinal symptom: Epigastric and/or periumbilical pain that radiates to the back, relieved by sitting & leaning forward.
  • Up to 90% of patients have nausea and/or vomiting that typically does not relieve the pain.
  • The nature of the pain is constant.
  • Dehydration, poor skin turgor, tachycardia, hypotension, & dry mucous membranes are commonly seen in patients with AP.
  • Mild pancreatitis: Abdomen may be normal or reveal only mild epigastric tenderness.
  • Severe pancreatitis: Significant abdominal distention, associated with generalized rebound tenderness and abdominal rigidity
  • Flank (Grey Turner), periumbilical (Cullen’s sign) & inguinal ecchymosis (Fox sign) are indicative of retroperitoneal bleeding associated with severe pancreatitis.

Isotonic crystalloid by IV line

“While there are proponents for aggressive fluid therapy and for specific resuscitation goals, it is probably best to resuscitate with a balanced crystalloid and to restore normal blood volume, blood pressure, and urine output. On the basis of recent data it appears that lactated Ringer’s solution may be superior to normal saline in reducing the systemic inflammatory response.”

questions.text: 68-years-old Esther was overweight and she has been done some changes to her lifestyle for decreasing her weight. Her medical history will reveal to us about diabetes - 20 years and was in hemodialysis for the past 5 years. She is regularly taking insulin injections. She added that her blood sugars were controlled by her dieting plans and exercises. Esther also had hypertension and dyslipidemia. Esther can be at great risk for which of the metabolic derangements?
questions.solution:
• Renal osteodystrophy can be caused by ESRD.
  • If it is failed kidney there will be reduced synthesize of active Vitamin D which will also cause for the decreased absorption of calcium from the intestine.
  • Phosphorous retention will be associated with ESRD which will bind with calcium and promote the hypocalcemia.
  • Hypocalcemia along with hyperphosphatemia will promote for the secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  • It will occur by stimulation of parathyroid gland.
  • Osteitis fibrosa cystica is occurred due to the high bone turnover rate seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Option B; In patients with ESRD hypercalcemia cannot be seen usually. In any renal pathology hypercalcemia is usually not seen. It can be seen in people who use excessive use of calcium containing phosphate binders.

Option C; This result from the decreased ability of clearing the inorganic phosphates by the failing kidneys. Increased bone turnover can accelerate the hyperphosphatemia.

Option D: This also not seen in patient with ESRD. Parathyroid gland can be stimulated excessively by combination of hypocalcemia with hyperphosphatemia which will result in secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text:
Identify the inheritance pattern:



1.
2.
questions.solution:
Pedigree chart is a diagram of a family history that illustrates relationships among family members; it shows which family members are affected by specific medical conditions.

Autosomal dominant inheritance

  • Individuals affected in every generation
  • Some carriers may not manifest disease
  • Males and females have an equal chance of passing on the mutation
  • 50% risk to children
  • Affected children must have at least one affected parent
  • Two affected parents can have an unaffected child

Autosomal Recessive:

  • Parents don't have to be affected, but both must at least be carriers (heterozygous for the trait)
  • Two affected parents will only have affected children
  • This trait often skips generations
  • The trait will also appear more often in children of related parents (consanguine, also known as incest)

X-Linked Dominant:

  • Both sexes are affected, but typically seen more in females
  • An affected son must have an affected mother
  • Affected males will pass on the trait to all of their daughters

X-Linked Recessive:

  • Both sexes are affected, but seen in males more frequently
  • Affected mothers will pass on the trait to all of their sons
  • The trait sometimes skips a generation

questions.text:
Which of the following statement(s) are correct regarding Caspases?

It is an alanine protease in nature
Active caspase is a marker for cells undergoing apoptosis.
Exists as zymogens and undergo cleavage to get activated
Independent of proapoptotic and antiapoptotic proteins
Required for embryogenesis
questions.solution:
Caspases

  • Cysteine proteases and are critical for the process of apoptosis.
  • Required at the time ofembryogenesislike implantation, organo­genesis, developmental involution, and metamorphosis.

Apoptosis:

  • Pathway of cell death that is induced by a tightly regulated suicide program
  • Apoptosis results from the activation of enzymes calledcaspases
  • Caspases exist as inactive proenzymes, or zymogens, and must undergo enzymatic cleavage to become active.
  • The presence of cleaved, active caspases is a marker for cells undergoing apoptosis.
  • The process of apoptosis may be divided into:

→Initiation phase,during which some caspases become catalytically active

→Execution phase,during which other caspases trigger the degradation of critical cellular components.

The activation of caspases depends on a finely tuned balance between production ofpro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic proteins.

questions.text: Reflex in which child's head flexes forward, extending the back of the neck, the upper extremities will contract and the lower extremities will extend. Conversely, when the child's head is extended backward, contracting the back of the neck, the upper extremities will extend and the lower extremities will contract and not present at birth. Name the reflex.
questions.solution:
Important Neonatal reflexes appearing after birth are parachute reflex & symmetric Tonic Neck reflex.

Symmetric tonic neck reflex:

  • When the child's head flexes forward, extending the back of the neck, the upper extremities will contract and the lower extremities will extend. Conversely, when the child's head is extended backward, contracting the back of the neck, the upper extremities will extend and the lower extremities will contract.
  • Appears at: 4-6 months
  • Disappears at: 8-12 months

Moro’s reflex:

  • Components: Symmetric abduction and extension of upper limbs along with opening of hands followed by flexion and adduction of upper limbs + extension of head and trunk, movement of lower limbs and crying
  • Appears at: 28-37 weeks
  • Disappears at: 5-6 months

Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR):

  • Elicited by rotation of head → causes extension of upper extremity on the side to which face is rotated and Flexion of upper extremity on the side of occiput
  • Appears at: 35 weeks
  • Disappears at: 5-6 months

Crossed extensor reflex:

  • When one of the baby's leg is held in extended position and a firm pressure is applied to the sole of the foot of the same leg→ The baby's free leg flexes, adducts and then extends.
  • Appears at: 30-34 weeks
  • Disappears at: 2 months of age

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with complaints of fever, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. The patient is having these symptoms after ingestion of meat 18hrs ago in lunch. Results from the sample sent to lab suggested Clostridial food poisoning. What is the most common type of Clostridium responsible for such condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of Clostridial food poisoning is Cl. perfringens type A.

Food poisoning by Clostridium:

  • Cause -Ingestion of cold and warmed-up meat dishes.
  • Incubation period - 8 to 24 hours.
  • Clinical feature:
    • Abdominal cramps and watery diarrhea.
    • Usually Absence of nausea, vomiting, or fever—are characteristic presentations of this condition.
    • Self-limiting and recovery within 24–48 hours.
  • Most common cause of gas gangrene- C. perfringens.
  • Type A strains are the most common.
  • These strains produce spores → heat resistant → produce enterotoxin (coded by gene cpe).

questions.text: A 67-year-old male, with complaints of persistent dry cough for the past 4 weeks which in turn was associated with intermittent fever and easy fatigability. On further history taking, he added that he experiences chest discomfort and breathing difficulty on exertion. On Examination SpO2 = 92% in Room Air, HR = 110 beats/min, RR = 18 breaths/min. Radiologic studies revealed symmetric hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy noted and a Cluster of Black Pearls sign is seen. On biopsy there is granuloma without necrotic center, this is typically seen in?
questions.solution:
• In granulomas associated with certain infectious organisms (most classicallyMycobacterium tuberculosis), a combination of hypoxia and free radical–mediated injury leads to a central zone of necrosis.
  • Grossly, this has a granular, cheesy appearance and is therefore calledcaseous necrosis.
  • Microscopically, this necrotic material appears asamorphous, structureless, eosinophilic, granular debris, with complete loss of cellular details.
  • The granulomas inCrohn disease, sarcoidosis, and foreign body reactionstend tonot have necrotic centersand are said to benon-caseating.

questions.text: Rani, a 27 yr old female with Obstetric score of G2P1L1,on term now complains of postural hypotension I.e.,complaints of faintness on lying down and she feels good when she turns to side or sitting position. Which of the following is the most probable cause for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
SUPINE HYPOTENSION SYNDROME (POSTURAL HYPOTENSION):

  • During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava when the patient is in supine position.
  • In 90% cases this, however, results in opening up of the collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygos veins.
  • In some cases (10%), when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed.
  • This results in production of hypotension, tachycardia and syncope called as supine hypotensive syndrome.
  • The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position.
  • That is why pregnant females are advised to lie in lateral positions best being left lateral.

questions.text:
True statement about Spigelian hernia:

Absence of posterior rectus fascia may contribute to an inherent weakness in the area
Recurrence common with this type of hernias
Larger defects are repaired using a mesh prosthesis.
Develop during 2 to 3 decades of life
questions.solution:
Spigelian hernia

  • It occurs through the Spigelian fascia
  • It is composed of an aponeurotic layer between rectus muscle medially & semilunar line laterally.
  • Nearly all Spigelian hernias occur at or below the arcuate line.
  • Absence of posterior rectus fascia may contribute to an inherent weakness in this area.
  • These hernias are often interparietal, with the hernia sac dissecting posterior to external oblique aponeurosis.
  • Spigelian hernia sac always penetrates the Spigelian aponeurosis & usually penetrates the internal oblique musculature

Clinical Features

  • Most Spigelian hernias are small (1-2 cm in diameter)
  • Develop during 4 to 7 decades of life.
  • Patients often present with localized pain in the area without a bulge because the hernia lies beneath the intact external oblique aponeurosis.

Diagnosis

  • Ultrasound or CT of the abdomen can be useful to establish the diagnosis

Treatment

  • A spigelian hernia is repaired because of the risk for incarceration associated with its relatively narrow neck.
  • Defect is closed transversely by simple suture repair of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles, followed by the closure of the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • Larger defects are repaired using a mesh prosthesis.
  • Recurrence is uncommon

questions.text:
With reference to Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVM) being used on vaccine vials, which of the following statements is/are correct?

It gives information about heat exposure over a period of time 2.
It directly indicates vaccine potency

Select the Answer using the code given below:
questions.solution: The VVM does not directly measure vaccine potency but it gives information about the main factor that affects potency i.e. heat exposure over a period of time. A vaccine vial monitor (VVM) is a label containing a heat sensitive material which is placed on a vaccine vial to register cumulative heat exposure over time. The combined effects of time and temperature cause the inner square of the VVM to darken, gradually and irreversibly. A direct relationship exists between the rate of colour change and temperature: • The lower the temperature, the slower the colour change. • The higher the temperature, the faster the colour change. The VVM is a circle with a small square inside it. It can be printed on a product label, attached to the cap of a vaccine vial or tube, or attached to the neck of an ampoule.

questions.text: A 31-year-old married male was sent for psychiatric evaluation following a quarrel. He had been caught rubbing his genitals against a coconut tree in the neighbor's house. The latter had come out and hit him resulting in a scuffle, followed by a psychiatric referral. A detailed history revealed disturbed childhood due to constant parental fights. The patient also had been sleeping in his parent's bedroom and had frequently observed them cohabiting. Subsequently, on reaching puberty he had indulged in the following sexual acts, i.e. masturbation with boys of his age, exposing himself to young girls and fondling their private parts, using ladies undergarments for self-stimulation. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
PARAPHILIAS:

  • These are disorders of sexual preference in which sexual arousal occurs persistently and significantly in response to objects which are not a part of normal sexual arousal.

TRANSSEXUALISM:

  • It is the severest form of gender identity disorders
  • There is a sense of discomfort with anatomical sex organs & desires to get rid of them i.e., dissatisfaction with allotted sex.
  • Phrases like - I am a male in a female body or vice versa are quite characteristic of it.
  • Observation for a long period of time is needed to be very certain of the diagnosis
  • Treatment: Sex Reassignment Surgery (SRS) with hormonal treatment

VOYEURISM:

  • Also known as scopophilia.
  • This is a persistent or recurrent tendency of watching others in the act of sex or undressing
  • This is often followed by masturbation to achieve orgasm
  • Almost always seen in males
  • Watching pornography is not included here.

PARAPHILIAS:

  • These are disorders of sexual preference in which sexual arousal occurs persistently and significantly in response to objects which are not a part of normal sexual arousal.

EXHIBITIONISM:

  • It involves exposing the genitals to become sexually excited or having a strong desire to be observed by other people during sexual activity.
  • The exhibitionistic disorder involves acting on exhibitionistic urges or fantasies or being distressed by or unable to function because of those urges and fantasies.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male came with pain and watering in the right eye for 36 hours. On examination a 3x2 cm corneal ulcer is seen with elevated margins as shown in figure. what is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
PATHOPHYSIOLOGY OF FUNGAL KERATITIS:

Fungi are a group of microorganisms that have rigid walls and a distinct nucleus with multiple chromosomes containing both DNA and RNA. Though often evolving insidiously, fungal keratitis can elicit a severe inflammatory response – corneal perforation is common, and the outlook for vision is frequently poor.

Two main types of fungi cause keratitis:

  1. Yeasts (e.g. genus Candida), ovoid unicellular organisms that reproduce by budding, are responsible for most cases of fungal keratitis in temperate climates.
  2. Filamentous fungi (e.g. genera Fusarium and Aspergillus), multicellular organisms that produce tubular projections known as hyphae.

They are the most common pathogens in tropical climates, but are not uncommon in cooler regions; the keratitis frequently follows an aggressive course. Symptoms. Gradual onset of pain, grittiness, photophobia, blurred vision, and watery or mucopurulent discharge. Candidal keratitis Yellow–white densely suppurative infiltrate is typical. Filamentous keratitis Grey or yellow–white stromal infiltrate with indistinct fluffy margins. Progressive infiltration, often with satellite lesions.

Feathery branch-like extensions or a ring-shaped infiltrate may develop. Rapid progression with necrosis and thinning can occur.

Penetration of an intact Descemet membrane may occur and lead to endophthalmitis without evident perforation.

An epithelial defect is not invariable and is sometimes small when present. Other features include anterior uveitis, hypopyon, endothelial plaque, raised IOP, scleritis, and sterile or infective endophthalmitis.

questions.text: The condition shown in the below-given picture gets fixed after
questions.solution:
The picture is showing Post mortem staining which get fixed after 6-8 hours.#help in ascertaining the postmortem interval.

Livor Mortis = postmortem hypostasis= postmortem lividity = postmortem staining = suggillations = vibices

  • With the cessation of circulation at the time of death, the blood gravitates into the toneless capillaries and venules in the dependent parts of the body
  • This passive pooling of blood into the dependent areas of the body, imparting purplish or reddish-purple discolouration to those areas, is known as postmortem hypostasis.
  • The distribution of hypostasis depends upon the posture of body after death. and so helpful in determining the last position of the dead.
  • In case of hanging: hypostasis will be more marked on dependent lower limbs, surrounding genitalia, hands and distal portions of the arms.
  • In case of drowning: postmortem staining is usually found on the face, the upper part of the chest, hands, lower arms, feet and lower legs

Cherry-pink or cherry-red colour: poisoning by carbon monoxide or hydrocyanic acid Chocolate or coffee-brown colour: poisoning by potassium chlorate, potassium bichromate or nitrobenzene, aniline, etc.

Dark brown colour: in poisoning by phosphorus.

Bright pink patches: refrigerated dead body

questions.text: A case of non-immune fetal hydrops was diagnosed at 31 weeks gestation with fetal hemoglobin of 5 g/dL. Due to fetal distress 18 hours later, the baby was delivered by emergency cesarean section and died two days later. Characteristic intra-nuclear inclusions in nucleated red blood cells were found in histopathological examinations of the liver and placenta. The probable pathogenic organism that led to this condition is:
questions.solution:
Parvovirus B19 during pregnancy

1. Spontaneous abortion

  • The spontaneous loss rate of fetuses affected with parvovirus B19 before 20 weeks?gestation is 14.8% and after 20 weeks?gestation is 2.3%. The reason is uncertain but may be related to multisystem organ damage.

2. Hydrops

  • Parvovirus B19 is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and stillbirth in women experiencing a primary infection but does not appear to be teratogenic.
  • Possible mechanisms are fetal anemia (due to the virus crossing the placenta) combined with the shorter half life of fetal red blood cells, leading to severe anemia, hypoxia and high output cardiac failure.
  • Other possible causes are fetal viral myocarditis leading to cardiac failure, and impaired hepatic function caused by direct damage of hepatocytes and indirect damage due to hemosiderin deposits.
  • The ultrasound signs in a fetus with hydrops, include ascites, skin edema, pleural and pericardial effusions and placental edema.

questions.text: Mani, 48 yr old male who is a chronic smoker and alcoholic and a known Hypertensive patient who is currently taking antihypertensives like amlodipine and atenolol. Recently when he came for monthly review, BP was noted to be 160/100mmhg. Hence the patient was referred to a Physician for further management. Which of the following defines resistant hypertension?

choices.text: Resistance to 2 or more antihypertensive drugs
Resistance to 3 or more antihypertensive drugs

questions.solution:
• Resistant hypertension refers to patients with blood pressures persistently more than 140/90 mmhg despite taking 3 or more antihypertensive drugs, including a diuretic in a reasonable combination and at full doses.
  • Resistant or difficult to control hypertension is more common in patients more than 60 yrs than in younger patients.
  • Resistant hypertension may be related to, Pseudoresistance (high office blood pressures, and lower home blood pressures), non adherence to therapy, Identifiable cause of hypertension (including obesity and excessive alcohol intake)

questions.solution:

Average time for HCG to return Normal level:

questions.text: Patient A and Patient B who noticed a lump in the right breast underwent right-sided modified radical mastectomy (MRM) after confirming that the mass is malignant. The next day, Patient A complained of pain along medial aspect of the right arm and Patient B presented with a condition shown in the image. This is due to:

choices.text: Injury to Musculocutaneous nerve; Neuroma pain
Injury to Thoracodorsal nerve; Neuroma pain
Injury to Intercostobrachial nerve; Phantom breast pain
Injury of Long thoracic nerve of Bell; Intercostobrachial neuralgia

questions.solution:
Four Pain Syndromes

  1. Phantom Breast Pain: Painful (often knife like or shooting) sensation that the removed breast is still present
  2. Intercostobrachial neuralgia: Usually known as post-mastectomy pain syndrome (PMP), consists of pain in axilla, medial upper arm and anterior chest wall and is often is caused by nerve damage during axillary node dissection.
  3. Neuroma Pain: Can occur from scars from either mastectomy or lumpectomy but is more common if surgery is followed by radiotherapy.
  4. Other Nerve Injury Pain: Can occur even if intercostobrachial nerve is spared and is more common in breast reconstruction and implants.
Complications of Mastectomy

Seroma

  • MC complicationQ, beneath skin flaps & axilla, occurs in 30% cases
  • Catheter is retained until drainage is <30 mL/day

Wound Infection

  • Majority are due to skin flap necrosis

Lymphedema

  • Occurs less frequently with the standard axillary dissections
  • Extensive LN dissection, radiation therapy, presence of positive LNs, obesity are predisposing factors°.

Injury to Long Thoracic (Motor) Nerve

  • Seen in 10% of all cases.
  • Result in a palsy of the Serratus anterior muscle (classical winged scapula)

Injury to Thoracodorsal Nerve

  • Leads to palsy of the latissimus dorsi muscle.
Redundant Axillary Fat Pad

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presented with 2 days of right upper abdominal pain. The pain worsened with deep breathing and body movements, which radiated to the right shoulder. Physical examination revealed tenderness on palpation of the right upper abdomen and tenderness to percussion of the lower ribs. Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT showed conspicuous increased perihepatic enhancement on the right lobe of the liver. Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome was diagnosed, which improved after azithromycin was administered. The probable infection associated would be:
questions.solution:
Fitz-Hugh–Curtis syndrome

  • It is a rare complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involving liver capsule inflammation leading to the creation of adhesions.
  • The major symptom and signs include an acute onset of the right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain aggravated by breathing, coughing, or laughing, which may be referred to the right shoulder. There is usually also tenderness on palpation of the right upper abdomen and tenderness to percussion of the lower ribs which protect the liver.
  • It occurs almost exclusively in women. It is usually caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (Chlamydia) or Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Gonorrhea) though other bacteria such as Bacteroides, Gardnerella, E. coli, and Streptococcus have also been found to cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome on occasion.
  • These bacterial pathogens cause a thinning of cervical mucus and allow bacteria from the vagina into the uterus and fallopian tubes, causing infection and inflammation. Occasionally, this inflammation can cause scar tissue to form on Glisson's capsule, a thin layer of connective tissue surrounding the liver.

questions.text:
Which of the following are correct statements regarding regulations of respiration?

Respiratory rhythm is generated by Prebotzinger complex
DRG generates the inspiratory RAMP signal
Apneustic → Causes slow & deep breathing
Pneumotaxic → Causes rapid & shallow breathing
questions.solution:
Regulation of Respiration: -

  • DRG
    • DRG & VRG are the centers in upper medulla
    • The DRG generates the inspiratory ‘RAMP’ signal, & is sent to the thoracic cage

↓

Inspiration begins

Prebotzinger complex: -

  • Present in upper medulla
  • Pacemaker for spontaneous breathing
  • Neurons of DRG & VRG synapse here
  • It controls the respiratory rhythm

Q. Respiratory rhythm is generated by?

Ans. DRG

Q. Respiratory rhythm is controlled by?

Ans. Prebotzinger complex.

  • Pneumotaxic centre & apneustic centre: - Controls rate and depth of breathing Pneumotaxic → Causes rapid & shallow breathing
  • Apneustic → Causes slow & deep breathing.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are True regarding extracellular fluid to intracellular fluid, except?

ECF is rich in K+
ECF volume is twice that of the ICF
ECF is rich in organic anion
There is high sodium and low potassium in ECF
questions.solution:
• Option A is incorrect. ICF is rich in K+; ECF has a low concentration of K+.
  • Option B is incorrect. Total body water(42 L) is 60% of body weight; out of which 2/3rd (28L) is ICF, 1/3rd (14L) is ECF.
  • Option C is incorrect. ICF is rich in organic anions, the proteins. Other anions in ICF are inorganic phosphate.
  • Option D is correct. There is high sodium and low potassium in ECF.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements: The strategy to eradicate poliomyelitis in India comprised of:

Conducting national immunisation days
Mopping up rounds with OPV
Acute flaccid paralysis surveillance
Public awareness through multimedia

Which of these statements are correct?
questions.solution: Some important point regarding Strategies for polio erdication in India: I. Conduct Pulse polio immunization days every year till poliomyelitis is eradicated. II. Sustain high levels of routine immunization coverage III. Monitor OPV coverage at district level and its below level IV. Improve Surveillance capable of detecting all cases of acute flaccid paralysis due to polio / non polio aetiology. V. Ensure rapid case investigation, including stool sampling for virus isolation VI. Followup of all cases of acute flaccid paralysis on 60 days to check for any residual paralysis VII. Conduct outbreak control for cases suspected or confirmed to poliomyelitis to stop transmission. VIII. Reporting all cases of acute flaccid paralysis in children under 15 years of age is mandatory IX. Mopping up (door to door immunization in high risk districts where wild polio virus is known or suspected)

questions.text: A 37 yr old male, a known Lepromatous leprosy patient, treatment was started. On examination, Hair loss , Peripheral nerve thickening was also noted. After the intake of drug, skin lesions and fever develop within few days. Which type of Hypersensitivity reaction leads to this clinical features?
questions.solution:
• Clinical diagnosis of the patient is type 2 lepra reaction.
  • Pathogenesis of type 2 lepra reaction is type 3 Hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type 2 lepra reaction/ Erythema nodosum leprosum occur exclusively in patients with lepromatous end of leprosy spectrum.
  • Most common clinical features are crops of painful erythematous papules that resolve spontaneously in few days to weeks. Concomitant fever, lymphadenitis, neuritis and anemia may develop.
  • Type 1 lepra reaction occurs in half of patients with border line forms of leprosy but not in patients with pure lepromatous disease. This type of Hypersensitivity is type 4 hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presents to the gynaecologist with complains of heavy menstrual cycles and does not wish to take injections or daily tablets. She insists on a hysterectomy but the doctor advices her otherwise. The doctor then recommends this intrauterine device that can help her with her menstrual problems and also provide effective contraception, but should be changed every 5 years. Which of the following is the CORRECT statement about this device?

choices.text: Releases 52 mg of progesterone every day

questions.solution:
The device discussed here is Mirena (LNG IUD system)

  • Contains 52 mg of Progesterone
  • 20mcg of progesterone released per day
  • Can be used upto 5 years

Health benefits of Mirena include:

  1. Reduction of blood loss, which benefits patients with anemia and dysfunctional uterine bleeding
  2. Reduction of pain and dysmenorrhea in endometriosis and adenomyosis
  3. Beneficial effect on fibroids
  4. Does not influence lactation or affect infant growth and development.
  5. Can be used in prevention and treatment of endometrial hyperplasia.
  6. Decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.
  7. Decreases the risk of PID and hence protects against ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital after one day of shortness of breath and 2 weeks of dull chest pain, and a non-purulent productive cough. On the first night, after four hours of sleep, the patient was awakened for the second time; she promptly sat up in bed, looked at her right arm, and yelled, “There’s blood all over my arm!”. The resident physician examined her arm and saw only a clean IV placement. The physician reassured her that there was nothing there, the patient sat still and allowed herself to be evaluated. She showed no signs of a formal thought disorder or of delusion, and she denied any hallucination apart from feeling and seeing blood on her arm; Speech was organized normally and neurological exam was normal. This could probably be:
questions.solution:
This case shows that even with no history of prior psychiatric or neurologic disorders, patients in the hospital can have quite striking hallucinations upon awakening. Given the high prevalence of hypnopompic hallucinations among normal persons, it is no surprise many clinicians tend to disregard isolated incidences such as the one described.

  • Hypnogogic hallucination - occur while going to sleep.
  • Hypnopompic hallucinations - occur while getting up from sleep
  • Jactatio capitis nocturna or rhythmic movement disorder is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements, usually of head and neck, before and during sleep.

HOW TO REMEMBER: think of moving your head on plugging in audio jack and nocturna implies it occur at night.

  • In reflex hallucinations, stimulus in one modality results in the development of hallucination in another modality

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient complains of fever and fatigue beginning 15 days ago accompanied by headache, weakness, palpitation, abdominal pain, and diarrhea a week later. On her physical examination, the temperature was 39°C, PR: 92/min, RR: 24/min, BP: 100/60 mmHg. Her sclerae were sub icteric; skin and conjunctivae were pale; lips and tongue were dry. After microbiological analysis, she was diagnosed with typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi. Which of the following is the best selective media that can be used for culturing the pathogen involved?

choices.text: Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar medium

questions.solution:
• Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar - Best selective and indicator medium used for the isolation of Salmonella species.
  • Bismuth sulphite, brilliant green - inhibitors→ hinder the growth of most bacteria while allowing salmonella to grow.
  • Ferrous sulphate- Reacts with H2S → formation of ferrous sulfide→brown-black coloration and also diffuses into the surrounding medium, giving a brown–black halo.

Option 1: Thiosulphate citrate bile salt agar(TCBS) is used for Vibrio.

Option 3: Sorbitol Mac Conkey agar -For EHEC (Enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli).

questions.text: You are a Medicine 1st yr resident at AIIMS, receiving a 75 yr old male patient with retrosternal chest pain for past 6 hours.ECG of the patient is done and shown below. Which of the following is done as the Primary management?
questions.solution:
• ECG shows ST segment elevated MI
  • Symptoms of Retrosternal chest pain is explained by the ECG findings
  • STEMI is best managed with Primary PCI with first medical contact to device time to be kept less than 90 minutes.
  • If the patient is seen in non PCI capable hospital DIDO time should be less than 30 minutes for thrombolysis.
  • The patient can be transferred from non PCI capable hospital to PCI capable hospital in case the first medical contact to device time is less than 120 minutes.
  • In the question there is no mention of any PCI/ non PCI capable hospital.

questions.text: Egocentrism refers to the child's inability to see a situation from another person's point of view. The egocentric child assumes that other people see, hear, and feel exactly the same as the child does. In the developmental theory of Jean Piaget, this is a feature of
questions.solution:
Stage Characterized by
Sensori-motor (Birth-2 yrs)

Differentiates self from objects

Recognizes self as agent of action and begins to act intentionally. e.g. pulls a string to set mobile in motion or shakes a rattle to make a noise

Achieves object permanence: realizes that things continue to exist even when no longer present to the sense (pace Bishop Berkeley)
Pre-operational (2-7 years)

Learns to use language and to represent objects by images and words

Thinking is still egocentric: has difficulty taking the viewpoint of others

Classifies objects by a single feature: e.g. groups together all the red blocks regardless of shape or all the square blocks regardless of color
Concrete operational (7-11 years)

Can think logically about objects and events

Achieves conservation of number (age 6), mass (age 7), and weight (age 9)

Classifies objects according to several features and can order them in series along a single dimension such as size.
Formal operational (11 years and up)

Can think logically about abstract propositions and test hypotheses systematically

Becomes concerned with the hypothetical, the future. and ideological problems

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy present with a palpable mass per abdomen. On imaging paraaortic lymph nodes were found to be enlarged. A biopsy from the lymph nodes showed a starry sky appearance. What is the likely underlying abnormality?
questions.solution: All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are highly associated with translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8 that lead to increased MYC protein levels. MYC is a master transcriptional regulator that increases the expression of genes that are required for aerobic glycolysis, the so-called Warburg effect. The tumour exhibits a high mitotic index and contains numerous apoptotic cells, the nuclear remnants of which are phagocytosed by interspersed benign macrophages. These phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic “starry sky” pattern. When the bone marrow is involved, aspirates reveal tumour cells with slightly clumped nuclear chromatin, two to five distinct nucleoli, and royal blue cytoplasm containing clear cytoplasmic vacuoles.

questions.text: If a private practitioner is convinced that the patient is suffering from homicidal poisoning, he is bound to inform the police or magistrate under.
questions.solution:
• If a private practitioner is convinced that the patient is suffering from homicidal poisoning, he is bound to inform the police or magistrate under Section 39 CrPC
  • Non-compliance is punishable under Section 176 IPC.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the correct statement regarding GI bleeding?

The sensitivity of angiography for detecting GI bleeding is about 10–20% as compared to nuclear imaging
Angiography can image bleeding at a rate of 0.05–0.1 ml/min or less
99m Tc-RBC scan will image bleeding at rates as low as 0.05–0.1 ml/min
Angiography will detect bleeding only if extravasation is occurring during the injection of contrast
questions.solution:
Mesenteric angiography

  • Selective angiography, using either the superior or inferior mesenteric arteries, can detect hemorrhage in the range of 0.5 to 1.0 mL/min.
  • Only employed in the diagnosis of ongoing hemorrhage.
  • Particularly useful in identifying the vascular patterns of angiodysplasias.
  • It may also be used for localizing actively bleeding diverticula.
  • Catheter-directed vasopressin infusion can provide temporary control of bleeding, permitting hemodynamic stabilization, although as many as 50% of patients experience rebleeding when the medication is discontinued.
  • It can also be employed for embolization.
  • Complications: Hematomas, arterial thrombosis, contrast reactions, and acute renal failure.

Radionuclide scanning

  • Radionuclide scanning with technetium-99m ( Tc)-labeled RBCs is the most sensitive but least accurate method for localization of GI bleeding.
  • With this technique, the patient’s own RBCs are labeled and reinjected.
  • The labeled blood is extravasated into the GI tract lumen, creating a focus that can be detected scintigraphically.
  • Initially, images are collected frequently and then at 4-hour intervals for up to 24 hours.
  • The tagged RBC scan can detect bleeding as slow as 0.1 mL/min and is reported to be more than 90% sensitive.
  • Unfortunately, the spatial resolution is lacking, and blood may move retrograde in the colon or distally in the small bowel.
  • Reported accuracy of localization is 40-60%, and it is particularly inaccurate in distinguishing right- from left-sided colonic bleeding

questions.text: Glycine is a major amino acid in mammals and plays an important role in metabolic regulation, anti-oxidative reactions, and neurological function. It is a precursor for the synthesis of variety of other molecules. All of the following are synthesized from Glycine EXCEPT-
questions.solution:
• For pyrimidines, two amino acids are required i.e. Aspartate and Glutamine.
  • Glycine as Precursor of Many Compounds

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy with retractive breathing from his birth was scheduled for a rigid bronchoscopic examination. The agent of choice for inhalational induction of anesthesia in pediatric procedures that can be used in this patient is:
questions.solution:
• Sevoflurane is an ether inhalation anaesthetic agent with low pungency, a non-irritant odour and a low blood: gas partition coefficient.
  • It can be rapidly and conveniently administered without discomfort, and its low solubility facilitates precise control over the depth of anaesthesia and a rapid and smooth induction of, and emergence from, general anaesthesia.
  • As an induction and maintenance agent for ambulatory and nonambulatory surgery in children, sevoflurane provides more rapid induction of, and emergence from, anaesthesia than halothane, and has similar or better patient acceptability.
  • Time to discharge from the recovery area is usually at least as fast with sevoflurane as with halothane. While rapid emergence from sevoflurane lessens the time spent under anaesthesia, postoperative pain may be more intense and occur earlier than during more gradual emergence.
  • Sevoflurane has been used successfully as an induction agent for tracheal intubation and laryngeal mask airway (LMA) insertion: time to LMA insertion is faster with sevoflurane than halothane, but the 2 drugs provide similar conditions for tracheal intubation.
  • The pattern and incidence of induction and emergence events such as cough, laryngospasm and agitation/excitement is similar with sevoflurane and halothane; however, sevoflurane may cause less postoperative nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A 65 yr old female, chronic hypertensive patient poorly controlled now presents with complaints of dyspnea. Pulse rate is 70/min while BP=110/70 mm Hg. On examination there is an early-diastolic murmur. Chest X ray done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis of this patient?

choices.text: Valvular lesion of left side of heart

questions.solution:
• The striking feature in this chest X-ray is the remarkably prominent main pulmonary artery segment (MPA), which appears to be dilated.

  • This X-ray also shows a prominent right atrial contour, indicating right atrial dilatation as a consequence of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • In view of prominent pulmonary artery segment with early diastolic murmur the clinical diagnosis is pulmonary artery hypertension causing a mild pulmonary regurgitation.
  • The female gender is suggestive of a connective tissue disorder that can lead to pulmonary artery hypertension.

questions.text: A patient visited the hospital with non-specific symptoms like fever, mild cough, rashes, etc. On further examination and testing, the physician is suspecting it to be an arboviral infection. Which of the following is true regarding arboviral infections?

choices.text: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is caused by inhalation of rodent feces
KFD is caused by the bite of wild animal
Lyssa virus is transmitted by ticks
Yellow fever is transmitted by Anopheles mosquito

questions.solution:
• All the above are false statements except Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is caused by inhalation of rodent feces.

Option 1: Hantaviruses:

  • Found worldwide.
  • Cause two serious and often fatal human diseases:
    • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome
    • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS).
  • Rodents are the reservoirs for hantaviruses.
  • The virus infections in rodents are lifelong and without deleterious effects.
  • Transmission to humans occurs by inhaling aerosols of rodent excreta (urine, feces, saliva).
  • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is generally severe, with reported mortality rates of 30% or greater.
  • The disease begins with fever, headache, and myalgia followed by rapidly progressive pulmonary edema, often leading to severe respiratory compromise.

Option 2, 3: KFD (Kyasanur forest disease) is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected hard ticks.

Option 4: Yellow fever is transmitted by Aedes mosquito.

questions.text:
Which of the following statement is correct about Gelle's test?

It is a test of bone conduction
It compares the intensity of sound with change of air pressure
Positive in a normal person
Positive in sensorineural hearing
questions.solution:
GELLE’S TEST:

  • Test of bone conduction & examine the effect ofraised air pressurein EAC on hearing.
  • Normally, when air pressure is increased in-ear canal by Siegel’s speculum, it pushes the tympanic membrane and ossicles inwards, raises intralabyrinthine pressure, and causes immobility of basilar membrane and decreased hearing, but no change in hearing is observed when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected.
  • Gelle’s test is performed by placing a vibrating fork on the mastoid while changes in air pressure in the ear canal are brought about by Siegel’s speculum.
  • Gelle’s test +ve in normal persons / sensorineural hearing loss. Negative when the ossicular chain is fixed( Otosclerosis) or disconnected.

questions.text: Awake is a 2007 American conspiracy thriller film. The film focuses on a man who experiences anesthesia awareness - a condition that leaves a person undergoing surgery aware of what's going on, sometimes even able to feel pain, but unable to scream or even move. Which of the following monitoring technique can be used to prevent such awareness:
questions.solution:
Intraoperative awareness

Current evidence-based practice research reveals that intraoperative awareness occurs in 1 to 2 patients per 1,000 receiving general anesthesia. This awareness can result in the patient feeling severe pain and experiencing long-term issues such as posttraumatic stress disorder. Intraoperative awareness is considered a sentinel event by The Joint Commission. BIS monitoring can prevent this occurrence by adding another clinical test to determine the depth of anesthesia

Symptoms of intraoperative awareness include:

  • responding to verbal commands
  • eyelash reflex still functioning
  • 20% elevation in heart rate or BP from the previous baseline
  • muscle tensing or movement
  • pupillary response

Bispectral index (BIS)

  • It is one of several technologies used to monitor depth of anesthesia.
  • BIS monitors are used to supplement Guedel's classification system for determining depth of anesthesia. Titrating anesthetic agents to a specific bispectral index during general anesthesia in adults (and children over 1 year old) allows the anesthetist to adjust the amount of anesthetic agent to the needs of the patient, possibly resulting in a more rapid emergence from anesthesia.
  • Use of the BIS monitor could reduce the incidence of intraoperative awareness during anaesthesia. The exact details of the algorithm used to create the BIS index have not been disclosed by the company that developed it.

questions.text: A 26-year-old army man presented to our hospital with complaints of breathlessness mostly on exertion, dry cough, and episodes of hemoptysis for the past 18 months. A digital chest radiograph was labeled normal from outside but on careful observation bilateral lower lobe infiltration was observed then HRCT was advised which showed early bronchiectatic changes in both lungs. Pulmonary function testing demonstrated a decrease in lung capacity with mild airflow. These characteristic Bronchiectatic features with dry cough is seen with?
questions.solution:
• Bronchiectasis sicca- all bronchiectasis features but the absence of the copious amount of sputum is usually a hallmark of bronchiectasis.

  • HRCT chest shows abnormal dilation of the tracheal bronchial tree; it is present without infective sputum and occurs due to tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with a swelling on the right side of her neck which had gradually enlarged. The patient was clinically euthyroid, and the rest of the examination was unremarkable, with the exception of a 2 cm firm smooth mass on the right side of the thyroid that moved with swallowing. Total thyroidectomy was performed. and the pathologic findings in the thyroid gland showed the following findings shown in the image. Your probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a neoplastic proliferation of parafollicular cells in nesting pattern with amorphous eosinophilic material depositions in stroma that was positive for amyloid staining suggesting Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Medullary Carcinoma Thyroid

  • Neuroendocrine carcinoma arising from parafollicular ‘C’ cells of the thyroid
  • Parafollicular ‘C’ cells are derived from the ultimobranchial bodies & secrete calcitonin
  • ‘C’ Cells are concentrated superolaterally in thyroid lobes, from where MTC usually develops
  • Most MTCs (75–80%) arise sporadically
  • Spread is both lymphatic & hematogenous
  • MC site of metastasis: Liver

Clinical Features

  • High level of serum Calcitonin & CEA
  • Cervical lymph nodes at the time of presentation (LN involvement, thyroid, and blood-borne metastases occur early)
  • Diarrhea at the time of presentation.
  • Amyloid in stroma histologically.
  • MEN setting: Evidence of Pheochromocytoma/Hyperparathyroidism/Thyroid cancer in the family. (Discovery of medullary carcinoma thyroid makes family surveillance advisable)

Diagnosis

  • Diagnosed by FNAC
  • I 131 scan is of no use as MTC is TSH independent.
  • Tumor marker: Calcitonin is raised in almost all cases of MTC
  • Calcitonin excess in MTC is not associated with hypocalcemia

Treatment

  • Total thyroidectomy + Central LN dissection ± Ipsilateral MRND if tumor >1 cm
  • If nodes are positive on the ipsilateral side: Bilateral MRN
  • Vandetanib (EGFR inhibitor) is the only drug approved by the US FDA for the treatment of advanced & progressive MTC

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presented with a 25-year history of epilepsy. She had a history of focal impaired awareness with cognitive changes and behavioral arrest progressing to bilateral tonic-clonic seizures. Magnetic resonance imaging displayed asymmetry of the hippocampus, with a prominent right temporal horn of lateral ventricle. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MESIAL TEMPORAL LOBE EPILEPSY SYNDROME

MTLE is the most common syndrome associated with focal seizures with impairment of consciousness.

High-resolution magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can detect the characteristic hippocampal sclerosis that appears to be essential in the pathophysiology of MTLE for many patients.

Recognition of this syndrome is especially important because it tends to be refractory to treatment with anticonvulsants but responds well to surgical intervention.

EEG - Temporal (Unilateral or Bilateral) spikes

MRI - Hippocampal sclerosis

OPTION A) Lennox-Gastaut syndrome occurs in children and is defined by the following triad:

  1. multiple seizure types (usually including generalized tonic-clonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures);
  2. an EEG showing slow (<3 Hz) spike-and-wave discharges and a variety of other abnormalities; and
  3. impaired cognitive function in most but not all cases.

OPTION C) Benign Rolandic epilepsy-Most common epilepsy in children

  • This common focal motor epilepsy is unique among the focal epilepsies of childhood in that it is self-limiting despite a very abnormal EEG pattern.
  • It is usually transmitted in families as an autosomal dominant trait and begins between 5 and 9 years of age.
  • It typically announces itself by a nocturnal tonic-clonic seizure with focal onset. Thereafter, the seizures take the form of clonic contractions of one side of the face, less often of one arm or leg, and the interictal EEG shows high-voltage spikes in the contralateral lower rolandic or centrotemporal area.
  • Seizures are readily controlled by a single anticonvulsant drug and gradually disappear during adolescence.

OPTION C) If a focal seizure continues for hours/days it is known as Epilepsia Partialis Continua.

questions.text: A 38-years old patient who had a total abdominal hysterectomy presents 2 months postop complaining of leakage of urine from the vagina. On examination, no fistula can be identified. Dilute methylene blue (100mL) is injected into the bladder through a Foley catheter and a tampon is placed in the vagina. The patient is asked to walk for about 15 minutes, after which the patient is found to be wet, but there is no blue stain anywhere on the tampon. Which of the following is true:-

choices.text: 100mL was probably not enough methylene blue, and the test should be repeated with a higher volume
The patient probably has stress incontinence not a fistula
The patient probably has a ureterovaginal fistula
The patient most likely has small apical vesicovaginal fistula that was too small to leak the dye in 15 minutes

questions.solution:
Methylene blue Swab Test—

A Catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra,

The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile swabs,

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder through the catheter.

  • If there is a VVF present, the methylene blue dye stains the uppermost swab.
  • If the lowermost swab gets stained, the leak is from the urethra--> urethrovaginal fistula
  • If the swabs do not take up the stain, but get wet with urine, the leak is from the ureter-->ureterovaginal fistula

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the marked structure?


The marked part is known as Korner's septum
.It is an anatomic boundary in the temporal bone
It is formed by the persistent Temporosquamous suture
It is formed by the persistent petro-squamous suture
questions.solution:
• Koerner's septum is an anatomic boundary in the temporal bone formed by the persistent petro-squamous suture that separates the superficial squamous cells from the deep petrosal air cells in an embryonic phase.
  • Korner’s septum lies lateral to the antrum and is surgically important as it may cause difficulty in locating the antrum and the deeper cells (Antrum is hidden medial to Koerner’s septum) and thus may lead to incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy.
  • The arrow in the image below shows Koerner’s septum present lateral to Mastoid antrum.

questions.text: Identify the type of septal fracture shown below & comment on fracture line?
questions.solution:
Picture shows fracture line above anterior nasal spine running backwards parallel to cartilage vomer junction: Jarjaway Fracture

JARJAWAY FRACTURE:

  • Fracture line starts just above the anterior nasal spine and runs horizontally backwards parallel and above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer.
  • It results from blows from the front

CHEVALLET FRACTURE:

  • Vertical fracture starts from anterior nasal spine and runs upwards towards the junction of bony and cartilaginous dorsum of nose.
  • It results from blows from below

  • GUERIN'S FRACTURE:Horizontal fracture of the maxilla. Also known asLe Fort I/ Floating fracture/ Low level fracture
  • Violent force over a more extensive area above the level of the teeth will result in Le Fort I fracture
  • Horizontal fracture line seen above the apices of the maxillary teeth, detaching the tooth bearing portion of the maxilla from the rest of the facial skeleton
  • Le Fort II:
  • Pyramidal or Subzygomatic fracture
  • Fracture line runs below the frontonasal suture from the thin middle area of the nasal bones down on either side, crossing the frontal process of maxillae and passes anteriorly across the lacrimal bones anterior to nasolacrimal canal. From this point the fracture line passes downwards, forward and laterally crossing the inferior orbital margin in the region of zygomaticomaxillary suture. The fracture line extends downwards and forwards and lateral to the transverse wall of antrum, just medial to the zygomaticomaxillary suture line.
  • Le Fort III:
  • The fracture line begins at the frontozygomatic suture along the lateral aspect of the internal orbit along the sphenozygomatic suture line to the inferior orbital fissure, extends medially across the floor of the orbit upto the medial wall of the orbit towards the dorsum of the nose where it crosses and proceeds to the opposite side in the same manner

questions.text: A 34wk GA lady presented with vaginal bleeding.She is 4 cm dilatedon a P/V examination and the fetus is in a high transverse lie. The previous USG showed a fundal placentation.USG showed translucency behind the placenta and the CTG (Cardiotocography) showed FHR of 170.The best line of management is:
questions.solution:
The present case is that of Abruptio Placentae . the management of abruption is to induce labour.

However, in this case, there is labour, Abruption and also a Transverse lie. So even if there is no fetal distress, a transverse lie in labour is enough indication to do an emergency cesarean section

questions.text: A 35 years old army personnel suddenly fall down while doing patrolling in Thar desert border in Rajasthan. He was immediately taken to Military hospital and assessed by Medical officer. On examination - he was unconscious and unresponsive and pulse was impalpable . ECG was done and diagnosis of PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity) was made. Which of following condition is least likely to be the cause of this condition ?
questions.solution:
• The 5 H and 5 T of pulseless electrical activity → PEA implies that electrical activity is seen on ECG but the pulse is absent.
  • The leading cause of PEA is hypoxia secondary to respiratory failure (40-50% cases) and hypovolemia.
  • Hydrogen ion depletion implies alkalosis whereas PEA occurs with acidosis.

5H

  • Hypovolemia
  • Hypoxia
  • Hydrogen ion (Acidosis)
  • Hypo/hyperkalemia
  • Hypothermia

5T

  • Toxins
  • Tamponade
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Thrombosis (heart: acute, massive MI)
  • Thrombosis (lungs massive PEE)

questions.text: A 33-year-old cricket player presented to OPD with complaints of headache and palpitations. O/E - He has a standing BP 190/100 mm Hg and on sitting BP-180/100 mm Hg. He also has an irregularly irregular rhythm, double apical impulse, and bilateral basal crepitations. But no murmurs could be auscultated and heart rate could not be determined. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Condition Features
Left atrial Myxoma More common in a young female with symptoms of myxoma platypnea and low cardiac output since the tumor limits the blood flow into the left ventricle.
Mitral regurgitation Ruled out as no murmur was auscultated in the patient
Cor pulmonale Ruled out as primary lung disease or findings of RVF are absent
LVH

Points in favor of diagnosis:

  1. Hypertension can lead to LVH causing double apical impulse.
  2. HTN can lead to diastolic dysfunction and impacts the atria leading to atrial fibrillation and irregular pulse
  3. Basal crepitations can be explained by atrial fibrillation.
  4. BP changes in standing and supine position are normal (less than equal to 10mm Hg)

questions.text: A 19-year-old primigravid woman at 42 weeks' gestation comes the labor and delivery ward for induction of labor. Her prenatal course was uncomplicated. Examination shows her cervix to be long, thick, closed, and posterior. The fetal heart rate is in the 140s and reactive. The fetus is vertex on ultrasound. Prostaglandin (PGE2) gel is placed intravaginally. One hour later, the patient begins having contractions lasting longer than 2 minutes. The fetal heart rate falls to the 70s. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Quickly administer Terbutaline (Short Acting B2 Agonist) to decrease uterine contractility (fetal HR is steeply decreasing)

questions.text:
(A) True or (B) False about the stages of anesthesia:

Stage of delirium include cessation of eyeball movement to beginning of paralysis of intercostals muscle
Plane 3 of Stage of Surgical Anesthesia is the true surgical anesthesia plane
Paradoxical ribcage movements is seen in Stage of Surgical Anesthesia
Skeletal Muscle becomes flaccid, weak pulse and decreased blood pressure are seen in Stage of Excitement
questions.solution:
Stages of anesthesia

1. Stage 1 (Stage of Analgesia or Disorientation)

  • From beginning of induction of general anesthesia to loss of consciousness.
  • Eye lash reflex lost

2. Stage 2 (Stage of Excitement or Delirium)

  • Loss of consciousness to onset of automatic breathing.
  • Disinhibtion, Delerium, Hypertension, Tachycardia occurs Because of Sympathetic stimulation
  • Airway manipulation is avoided
  • Respiration is Rapid irregular
  • Eyelash reflex disappear, but other reflexes intact (cough, vomiting)

3. Stage 3 (Stage of Surgical Anesthesia)

  • Stage of automatic respiration to paralysis of respiration.
  • Divided into 4 planes

Plane 1

  • From onset of automatic respiration to cessation of eyeball movement.
  • Eyelid reflex is lost, Conjuctival reflex lost
  • Swallowing reflex is lost
  • Marked eyeball movement

Plane 2

  • Cessation of eyeball movement to beginning of paralysis of intercostals muscle.
  • Laryngeal reflex lost
  • Secretion of tear increases
  • Respiration is automatic and regular
  • Intermittent cessation of respiration
  • Loss of eye ball movement

Plane 3

  • Complete relaxation of intercostals & Abdominal muscles
  • Loss of pupillary light reflex

This is the true surgical anesthesia plane

Plane 4

  • Complete intercostals paralysis to diaphragmatic paralysis.
  • Irregular respiration
  • Paradoxical ribcage movements
  • Diaphragm paralysis

4. Stage 4: (Overdose)

  • Respiratory cessation to potential death
  • Skeletal Muscle becomes flaccid, weak pulse, Decreased Blood pressure

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to ER after a motorbike accident. On examination injury to the right leg associated with exposure of underlying bone and skin loss was noted. The best procedure to be done is an :
questions.solution:
Pedicel Graft or Flap

  • Flap: A partially or completely isolated segment of tissue with its own blood supply

Absolute Indications for Flaps

  • Exposed bone
  • Radiated vessel
  • Brain
  • Open joint or non-biological Q implant materials
  • Pressure sores at bony prominences

For critical and small areas such as an eyelid, a full-thickness graft is selected, so that contraction of the grafted material is minimum.

questions.text: A substance was identified in the lab that can specifically block the transport of glucose in the proximal renal tubule. If this substance is administered to the healthy individual, glucose clearance can be approximately equal to clearance of which of the following
questions.solution:
No tubular reabsorption tubular secretion or secretion. Excreted amount will be Filtered amount will be than filtered amount equal to excreted amount equal to excreted amount Net tubular reabsorption Excreted amount will be less than filtered amount Net More
  • Glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule and filtered at the glomerulus.
  • Glucose clearance and the GFR value will almost be equal when there is a blockage of sodium coupled, career mediated transport of glucose by proximal tubule.
  • This can be easily calculated by the clearance of inulin.

Option A; PAH can be freely filtered at the glomerulus and is getting secreted into the urine by an acid transporter in the proximal tubule. This is an energy dependent transporter. Filtered load will be lower than the amount of PAH. Renal plasma flow can be calculated by the clearance of PAH. Creatinine is not having that much similarity to PAH.

Option B; Under normal conditions, amino acids are filtered at the glomerulus same as that of glucose and then get reabsorbed at proximal tubule.

Option D; Sodium is a substance which is completely reabsorbed by the nephron, which results in a low amount excretion and a clearance value which will be very much lower than the GFR. Usually filtered sodium which is excreted will be 1%.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presented with complaints of distention of the abdomen, loss of appetite, and vague abdominal discomfort for 3 months duration. There was no associated menstrual complaint. A USG of the abdomen and pelvis revealed bilateral mixed solid and cystic adnexal masses along with ascites. A diagnosis of ovarian malignancy was made, based on which Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy were done. Histopathology report of the specimen showed mucinous papillary cystadenocarcinoma in both the ovaries. 5 months after completion of treatment, she complained of backache and abdominal pain and was advised for an X-ray lumbar spine suspecting Bone metastasis. The better investigation for detecting metastases to bones would be:
questions.solution:
• A bone scan is a functional study (gamma-imaging) done by injecting bone-specific agents like Tc99m-Methyl diphosphonate and looking for the site of uptake in the various bones. It is an exquisitely sensitive test for detecting bone secondaries although specificity is lower than that of MRI.
  • Although MRI is more specific and if not more, equally sensitive to Bone scan, but even today a whole-body MRI is less preferred than a bone scan for detecting osseous metastases.

Option A: A Tc99m-MDP Bone scan is certainly a better investigation for detecting osseous metastases.

Options B & D: Gallium-67 Bone scan and Indium-111 Bone scan - used mainly for infective/inflammatory pathologies like osteomyelitis, intraabdominal abscess, IBD, and sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presented with a 9-month history of right groin and anterior thigh pain without injury. The pain intensified at night and was only partially alleviated by NSAIDs and analgesics. On physical examination, she limped with an antalgic gait and had limited ROM of her hip, with 0° to 100° flexion and 0° internal rotation. The pelvic, hip, and lumbar spine radiographs were normal. A CT scan showed an oval, lytic lesion with a 6-mm central nidus at the bottom of the acetabulum with expansion of the quadrilateral plate from the pelvis. Your probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Cortical bone (80%) is the most common lesion site for Osteoid osteoma; intramedullary and trabecular sites are less common, and subperiosteal is rare. The acetabulum is an uncommon but painful location often associated with children. There have been numerous reported cases of Osteoid osteoma in the acetabulum. Juxtaarticular and intraarticular localizations frequently are associated with a delayed diagnosis, as seen in our patient.

  • An osteoid osteoma causes a dull, aching pain that is moderate in intensity but can worsen and become severe especially at night. The pain is not usually related to activity. In some cases, a person will suffer the aching bothersome pain of an osteoid osteoma for years.
  • Depending on the location of the tumor, there may also be swelling.
  • A CT scan provides a cross-sectional image of your bone and can also be helpful in evaluating the lesion. A CT scan will commonly show the nidus or center of the tumor.
  • A biopsy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis of osteoid osteoma.
  • Most osteoid osteomas will disappear on their own over several years. For some patients, regular use of NSAIDs, such as aspirin, ibuprofen, and naproxen, provides pain relief.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:

Registration of birth, even if the child is born in a hospital, is essentially the responsibility of parents only.
At present, the registration of birth has to be done not more than 15 days after the birth.

Which of these statements is/are correct?
questions.solution: The Central Births and Deaths Registration Act, 1969 came into force on 1st April 1970. This act fixes responsibility for reporting birth and death to public (parent, relative etc.,), to report events occurring in their households, Head of hospital or nursing homes, hotels, jails or dharmshalas are to report incidence occurring in such places to the concerned registrar. Time limit for registering births or deaths is 21 days in all over India. If late there is provision of late fee.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer was brought to the hospital with numerous sinus and swelling on his foot from which there was a continuous flow of discharging granules. Which of the following is false about the given condition?

choices.text: Can affect lower and upper extremities
Caused by actinomycetes and filamentous fungi
Diagnosis is by examination of pus

questions.solution:
Mycetoma:

  • A chronic, slowly progressive granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues.
  • Caused by actinomycetes and filamentous fungi.
  • Can affect lower and upper extremities

Triad of:

  • swelling
  • discharging sinuses
  • presence of granules in the discharge.

Laboratory Diagnosis: Diagnosis is by examination of pus / discharge

  • Direct Examination: Granules present in discharge/ pus are thoroughly washed in sterile saline; crushed between the slides and examined.
  • Mycetoma is endemic in Africa, India and the Central and South Americas.
  • Overall, actinomycetoma is more common (60%) than eumycetoma (40%) globally.

Note: BOTRYOMYCOSIS is a mycetoma like lesion → mainly caused by Staph. aureus.

The margins of the cone biopsy specimen are free of disease. What is your Diagnosis?

Microinvasive carcinoma of the cervix

Invasion depth limited to no greater than 5 mm,

Not visible to Naked eye

Stage I

Limited to Cervix

IA2 :Stromal invasion 3 mm-5 mm in depth

questions.text: The patient presents with varicose vein with saphenofemoral incompetence and normal perforator. Management options include all of the following except:
questions.solution:

  • Treatment of Varicose Veins - Saphenofemoral flush ligation with ligation of tributaries and stripping of a major part of the incompetent trunk

questions.text: Silver stain performed on renal biopsy shows characteristic findings as shown below. Immunostaining for Anti-PLA2R is positive. Based on the given findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Membranous nephropathy

  • By light microscopy, the glomeruli either appear normal in the early stages of the disease or exhibituniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall.
  • On electron microscopy,irregular electron-dense depositscontaining immune complexes between the basement membrane and the overlying epithelial cells witheffacementofpodocytefoot processes.
  • Basement membrane material is laid down between these deposits, appearing asirregular spikesprotruding from theGBM.
  • Antibodies against the podocyte antigenphospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R)are present.
  • Membranous nephropathy occurs secondary to other conditions as follows:
    • Autoimmune diseases (SLE)
    • Infections (syphilis, chronic hepatitis B, malaria)
    • Malignant neoplasms (Carcinoma colon, lung, and melanoma)
    • Drugs (captopril, NSAIDs, penicillamine)
    • Exposure to inorganic salts (mercury, gold)

questions.solution:
• Reticulocytes are stained in living statein vitroso it is called assupra­vital staining.

questions.text: A 48 yr old woman came with the complaints of Severe abdominal pain which intensifies after a fatty meal usually. Physician detected stones in the gall bladder on an ultrasound scan. Surgery was done and gall bladder was removed. Brown pigmented stones were extracted from the removed gall bladder. What is the main cause of gall stone pigmentation?

choices.text: Shigella infection. HMG CoA reductase release.
Bile supersaturated with cholesterol. Beta-glucoronidase release.

questions.solution:
Bacterial infection-mediated release of beta-glucoronidase results in formation of pigmented gall stones, especially the brown stones. The release of beta-glucoronidase leads to the formation of bilirubin glucoronides; levels of unconjugated bilirubin rise and result in the brown pigment of the stones.

Cholesterol stones can be present in different colours ranging from yellow to dark green and are mainly due to the supersaturation of bile with cholesterol. Brown stones are associated with infected bile and are found in intrahepatic or extrahepatic ducts outside the gallbladder. Pigmented stones are associated with gallbladder infection (especially with E. Coli and Klebsiella).

questions.text: A 43-year-old male came in to your OPD with complaints of excessive thirst. After collecting history, you notice that the patient has polyuria and polyphagia. You suspect it could be DM and order for FBS, PPBS & HbA1c. The HbA1c was about 12% and both the blood sugar values were over 240. You decide to start the patient on S/C Insulin therapy, and educate the patient regarding the same. What would you comment on its action, to the intern posted under you?
questions.solution:
• Insulin acts by stimulation of Tyrosine kinase receptor → enzymatic receptor.
  • Full insulin receptor consists of two covalently linked heterodimers.
  • containing α subunit, which is entirely extracellular and constitutes the recognition site,
  • and a β subunit that spans the membrane.
  • The β subunit contains tyrosine kinase.

A 3-year-old female child was brought to the emergency department with a history of retained disc battery in the nose. Which of the following statement is true about the scenario?

choices.text: Keep on instilling nasal drops intermittently till the foreign body dislodges
Keep the battery as it is and refer to higher expertise for elective removal
Battery contents might leak resulting into chemical damage of the surrounding tissue
Elective removal, as the child has a high risk of contracting tetanus

questions.solution:
• Disc batteries (also called button cell batteries) are found in toys, watches, hearing aids, cameras, calculators, and some remote-controlled devices.
  • These batteries are small, usually less than 0.5 in. (1.3 cm) across, and can be easily inserted into the nose.
  • A disc battery in the nose must be removed immediately.
  • The moist tissue in the nose can cause the battery to release strong chemicals (alkali) quickly, often in less than 1 hour.
  • This can cause serious damage to the sensitive mucous membranes lining the nose.
  • If a child has a disc battery in the nose, do not use nose drops or sprays of any type.
  • This can cause the battery to corrode more quickly.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with an eight-month history of shortness of breath and palpitations. Additionally, he had a recent history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. An echocardiogram demonstrated an atrial septal defect (ASD), a severely dilated right atrium, and ventricle. Which of the following is the most common type of ASD?
questions.solution:
Types of ASD:

Name Remarks
Ostium secundum Located in the central portion of atrial septum; Most common type of ASD
Ostium primum Located at lower part of the atrial septum
Sinus venosus defect Located at junction of superior vena cava and right atrium
Coronary sinus defect Refers to unroofed coronary sinus which is a rare communication between the coronary sinus and the left atrium

questions.text: A young female, came in with the complains of Primary amenorrhea. On general examination, Normal breast, Normal pubic hair was seen appropriate to her age. On further evaluating the patient, USG was done which reveals absent uterus and cervix with short vaginal pouch and normal ovaries. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mullerian Agenesis:

  • Congenital absence of both uterus and vagina is referred as mullerian agenesis or mayer rokitansky kuster hauser syndrome.
  • In Classic mullerian agenesis, patients have a shallow vaginal pouch only measuring upto 1.5 inches deep. In addition, the uterus, cervix and upper part of the vagina are absent.
  • Typically, a portion of the distal fallopian tubes are present. In addition , normal ovaries are present, given their separate embryonic origin.
  • Most patients with MRKH syndrome have only small rudimentary mullerian bulbs without endometrial activity.
  • Surgical excision of symptomatic rudimentary bulbs is required. With mullerian agenesis, traditional conception is impossible, but pregnancy may be achieved using sophisticated technology involving oocyte retrieval, fertilization and implantation into a surrogate.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man was admitted to the thoracic surgery department because of dysphagia. Chest radiograph and Barium swallow were normal. Rigid esophagoscopy under GA revealed no abnormality. Unfortunately, a small perforation occurred at the esophagus during the procedure. The most common site that you would expect the esophageal perforation to be is at:
questions.solution:
Esophageal perforation

Iatrogenic Spontaneous
  • Most common type
  • Caused by endoscopy
  • MC site is the cervical esophagus (cricopharyngeal area)
  • Esophageal rupture after vomiting
  • MC site: left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct?

Contraction of mesangial cells increases hydrostatic pressure of glomerulus
Contraction of mesangial cells increases hydrostatic pressure of bowman’s capsule
Efferent artery constriction decreases RBF
Mild constriction of efferent artery decreases GFR
questions.solution:
• Option A: FALSE → Mesangial cells → Decrease the surface area of basement membrane and have an action similar to smooth muscle contraction → Constrict the Glomerular capillaries →Reduced blood flow → Decreased hydrostatic pressure of glomerulus → Decreased GFR
  • Option B: FALSE → GFR ↓↓ → less filtrate flows in the Bowman's capsule → Decreased Hydrostatic pressure of Bowman's capsule
  • Option C: TRUE → Efferent Artery Constriction → Blood leaving and entering glomerulus per unit time is less → Decreased RBF
  • Option D: FALSE → Mild Constriction → Blood stays back in glomerular capillaries → Increased hydrostatic pressure → Increased GFR
