questions.text: The following microscopic appearance is that of a tumor commonly involving the cerebellopontine angle. What does the histopathology show?
questions.solution: Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it, a feature that simplifies surgical excision. Grossly, these tumors form firm, gray masses. Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively. The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is common and “nuclear-free zones” that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies. In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix that may be associated with microcyst formation.

questions.text:
A patient came to ENT OPD with complaints of earache, tinnitus, sensation of blocked ear. On examination, impacted wax is seen and the following procedure is performed.

Which of the following statement is true regarding the procedure?

choices.text: Ear pinna is pulled upwards and backwards and cold water is delivered along posterosuperior wall of EAC.
Ear pinna is pulled upwards and forwards and cold water is delivered along anterosuperior wall of EAC.
Ear pinna is pulled upwards and forwards and water at body temperature is delivered along anterosuperior wall of EAC.
Ear pinna is pulled upwards and backwards and water at body temperature is delivered along posterosuperior wall of EAC.

questions.solution: Pinna in pulled upwards backwards and laterally so that the cartilaginous and bony EAC lie in straight line and the tympanic membrane is visible. Then water boiled and cooled to body temperature is delivered to posterosuperior part of EAC, such that the pressure of water built up deeper to the, expels the wax out. Cold and Hot water are avoided as it would stimulate the labyrinth and cause vertigo.

questions.text: A middle-aged man diagnosed of having T3N1M0 stage of carcinoma of larynx. Among the following, which is the best treatment modality for this patient?

choices.text: Total laryngectomy with neck dissection and post-operative radiotherapy to the neck

questions.solution:
This patient is in stage III carcinoma of larynx.

N1= Single ipsilateral lymph node 3 cm

T3= Vocal cord fixation

M0= No distant metastases

In the past, advanced-stage larynx cancer (Stages III and IV) was treated by dual-modality therapy with radiation and surgery.

For most T3 and T4 tumors, where total laryngectomy is required for the complete removal of the tumour with amply clear margins along with radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 25 years old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, and bilateral nasal blockage for one year. She has a history of asthma and allergy. On examination, multiple ethmoidal polyps are noted with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions in both the nasal cavities. Biopsy is taken and the material is cultured which shows the growth of many hyphae with dichotomous branching typically at 45 degrees. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism?
questions.solution:
The most likely responsible organism is Aspergillus fumigatus.

1. Key points towards diagnosis:

  • Recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockade.
  • History of asthma and allergy
  • Hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45 degree

2. All points go towards Aspergillus infection.

  • Most common type of fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses are due to Aspergillus.
  • Aspergillus has septate hyphae that branch typically at 45 degrees (V-shaped).

3. Hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45 degrees:

Answers to other options:

  • Broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching seen in members of Zygomycetes. i.e Rhizopus and Mucor
  • Candida: Gram-positive oval budding yeast cell with pseudohyphae.

Enalapril

questions.text: A 63 yr old male patient presents with Periorbital swelling after 4 hours of trauma as shown in the image below. On examination, crepitus is palpated over the periorbital swelling. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows the presence of subcutaneous emphysema which is also subsequently confirmed on the physical examination as crepitus is palpated.
  • Chest trauma, a major cause of subcutaneous emphysema, can cause air to enter the skin of chest wall from neck or lung.
  • Renal shut down is ruled out because it would not happen within 4 hours of trauma.
  • Gas gangrene will again take time to develop and would lead to development of crepitus in injured part.

Causes of subcutaneous emphysema:

  • Trauma to parts of the respiratory system other than the lungs, such as rupture of a bronchial tube, may also cause subcutaneous emphysema.
  • May also occur with fractures of facial bones, neoplasms, during asthma attacks.

Mechanism:

  • When the alveoli of the lung are ruptured , as occurs in pulmonary laceration, air may travel beneath the visceral pleura, to the hilum of the lung, up to the trachea, to the neck and then to the chest wall.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of pain, itching, difficulty in hearing, and yellowish-green liquid discharge from ears. The patient was sent for sample culture to the microbiology laboratory. Which of the following selective medium is used for culturing the organism causing the given condition?
questions.solution:
• Selective medium for Pseudomonas is cetrimide agar.

Pseudomonas:

  • Resistant to many common antiseptics like quaternary ammonium compounds, chloroxylenol, and hexachlorophene.
  • Indeed selective media have been devised incorporating Dettol or cetrimide.

Other options:

  • Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter.
  • Regan Lowe medium is selective for Bordetellapertussis.
  • Ashdown's medium is selective for Burkholderia pseudomallei.

questions.text: Autopsy of the 25-year-old man who had been stabbed to death by unidentified men revealed multiple stab wounds which were elliptical in shape, both ends pointed and were gaping in the thorax and abdomen. There were also lacerations ranging from 10 - 15 cms on the forearms and shoulder. Which statement among the following is true about stab wounds?

choices.text: penetrating stab has wound of entry and exit

questions.solution:
STAB WOUND

  • The force is delivered along the long axis of a pointed object (eg. knife, scissors, needle, pencil etc) into the body.
  • Depth is the largest dimension.

Penetrating wound: When the weapon pierces through the body and enters into a body cavity or viscus.

Perforating wound: When the weapon pierces through the whole thickness of any part of the body thus producing two surface wounds, i.e. wound of entrance and wound of exit.

  • The entrance wound is bigger than the exit wound due to tapering of the blade of the weapon and its margins will be inverted, whereas the margins of the exit wound will be everted.
  • The track of the stab wound, starting from the entrance towards its termination, is convergent in contradiction to the track of a wound produced by a missile at short ranges where it is divergent

# Length is the maximum dimension in case of an Incised wound.

questions.text: Cardiac muscles undergo depolarization to initiate contraction. Among the following, the last part of the ventricle to be depolarized is?

choices.text: Epicardium of the base of LV
Endocardium of the base of LV

questions.solution:
• The endocardial surfaces of both ventricles are activated rapidly, depolarization spreads from apex to base and from endocardium to epicardium at a slower velocity ( ≈ 0.3 to 0.4 m/sec).
  • Thus, the last part of the heart to be depolarized is the epicardium of the base of the LV.
  • In addition, the apical and central epicardial regions of both ventricles are activated somewhat earlier than their respective basal regions.
  • The last portions of the ventricles to be excited are the pulmonary CONUS, posterior basal epicardial regions, and a small zone in the basal portion of the interventricular septum.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1L0 presents at 26 weeks for antenatal examination. She has a history of previous preterm pains at 28 weeks, and the baby did not survive. Which of these is the correct sequence of USG presentation of shape of cervical canal while progressing into preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of preterm labour includes:

  • uterine contractions
    • 4 times in 20 minutes
    • 8 times in an hour
  • On P/V examination, if cervix is
    • ≥1 cm dilated
    • 80% effaced
    • Short cervix
    • < 2.5 cm (Y-shaped)

NOTE: option 2 is preferred over option 1 or option 3 here, as T shaped cervical canal implies a normally closed cervix and not the one progressing into preterm labour.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the given contraceptive except-

choices.text: It contains 30 µg of Ethinyl estradiol
It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator
It is helpful in preventing osteoporosis
Needs to be taken twice a week for the first 3 months and then once a week

questions.solution:
• Centchroman(Ormeloxifene)is a non-hormonal, non-steroidal contraceptive.
  • Centchroman is a weekly pill that needs to be taken twice a week for the first 3 months and then once a week.
  • Its effect begins after a month.
  • Recently, Govt. of India has included Centchroman in the National Family Planning initiative for its distribution to women free of cost under the brand nameChhaya.(Previously SAHELI)
  • This is the only anti-implantation agent approved for clinical use in the world.
  • Pearl Index - 1.83-2.84/HWY.
  • Contraindicated in PCOD.

Consider the following statements:

Land filling for source reduction
Vaccination of pigs in the risk area
Immunization of children in risk area

Which of the above are the recommended control strategies for Japanese encephalitis?
questions.solution:
Some important points regarding control of Japanese encephalitis virus:

1. Vector control

  • By fogging the aerial and ground by ultralow volume insecticide (malathion, fenitrothion).
  • Uninfected village falling within 2-3 km radius of the infected village should also receive spray.
  • Use of mosquito net.
  • Mosquitoes source reduction by landfilling, leveling, and drainage of breeding place and water management.

2. Vaccination

  • Vaccination of population at risk.
  • Three types of vaccines available: a. Mouse brain – derived vaccine which is based on Nakayama or Beijing strain of JE virus. b. Cell culture - derived Beijing P-3 strain of JE virus. c. Cell culture - Cell culture derived live attenuated vaccine based on SA 14-14-2 strain of JE virus.
  • For children of 1-3 years of age, the dose schedule of brain-derived vaccine is two primary doses 1 month apart, first booster dose after 1 year, then at 3 years interval for 10-15 years.
  • The dose schedule of SA 14-14-2 vaccine is one single dose followed by one booster dose at 1 year of age.
  • Vaccine available in India as integral part of Universal Immunization Programme in Uttar Pradesh, Assam, West Bengal, and Karnataka.
  • Vaccine not recommended for children below 6 months of age.
  • The person visiting endemic countries of this disease for more than 2 weeks need 3 doses of vaccine at 0, 7, and 28.
  • Vaccination of pigs is extremely important for both public health and economic reasons.

Nested case control study:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with asymptomatic, well-demarcated, red-brownish patches involved both axillae and both crural areas of many months duration. Skin biopsy revealed coccobacilli and filaments of Corynebacterium minutissimum in the stratum corneum as shown in the image. Your probable diagnosis would be
questions.solution:
Erythrasma:

  • Erythrasma is a superficial cutaneous infection characterized by red-brown, wrinkling, possibly scaling, possibly pruritic, well-demarcated plaques in flexural areas, including the interdigital, axillary, inguinal, intergluteal, and submammary folds
  • Caused by corynebacteriumminutissimum
  • Clinically present with a non-itchy rash over axilla (MC site) > groin
  • When examined under wood’s lamp show coral-red fluorescence which is due to coproporphyrin III

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the hospital with complaints of profuse watery diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. The patient specified that his stools looked like rice water. The condition was diagnosed as cholera by the physician. Which of the following serotype causes Cholera?
questions.solution:
Cholera is caused by V. cholerae O1 and O139.

  • Cholerae is serotyped on the basis of ‘O’ antigen into several ‘O’ serotypes.

V. cholerae O1:

  • Has 2 Biotypes: Classical and El Tor.
  • 3 subserotypes: Ogawa, Inaba, Hikojima.

V. cholerae O139:

  • Clinical features similar to O1.
  • Known as Bengal V. cholerae, as it was isolated from Bengal in 1992.

Features of V. cholerae O1 and O139:

O1 and O139 produce the cholera toxin (Mechanism is shown in the image below):

O1 and O139 causes cholera, with the following features:

  • Rice watery stool.
  • Shortest incubation period: 1-2 days
  • Infective dose: 106-8 bacilli.
  • Transmission: Feco oral, direct contact.

NAG vibrios:

  • Non-Agglutinable Vibrio.
  • Not agglutinated in 01 serum.
  • Does not cause cholera.

questions.text: A baby girl was declared dead on arrival at the hospital. The husband and his family allege that the baby was born dead but the woman alleges that the baby was fine at birth but the local midwife had conspired with her in-laws to kill the child as they didn't want a girl child. The forensic doctor will perform all of the following tests to detect live birth, except?
questions.solution:
TESTS FOR LIVE BORN VS DEAD BORN

Hydrostatic rest or raygart’s test:

  • The specific gravity ofunrespired lung is 1.04,
  • which isreduced to 0.94 after respiration.
  • Since during respiration the specific gravity is reduced, it will float on water.

Fodere’s test:

  • Weight of the unrespired lung is 30g, which becomes 60g after respiration.
  • due to increase in blood flow after respiration.

Plocquet’s test:

  • The ratio of weight of lung to weight of body almost doubled after respiration,
  • from 1:70 before respiration to 1:35 after respiration

Breslau’s second left test:

  • Checks whether the stomach is floating or sinking.
  • If the body has respired the stomach will float due to the swallowed or ingested air during breathing.

Werden’s test:

  • presence of air in middle ear after respiration.
  • Dip ears in water, puncture tympanic membrane, if air escape - Live birth

#Gettler’s test:To check chloride content in heart. (If difference between right and left heart chloride content is 25% or more, it is suggestive of antemortem drowning )

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to a hospital with fever, nausea, and itching in the perineal region. On examination by a urologist, he is diagnosed as having infected bulbourethral glands. Which of the following structures is affected by this infection?
questions.solution:
• Bulbourethral glands present in deep perineal pouch and may involve contents there, including deep transverse perineal muscles.
  • Transverse perinei superficialis and bulbospongiosus lie in superficial perineal pouch.
  • Levator ani muscle lies quite deep, as the pelvic diaphragm.

Things to remember:

Deep perineal pouch (between perineal membrane below & superior fascia of urogenital diaphragm above). Contains:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Deep transverse perinei
  • Sphincter urethrae (external sphincter)
  • Bulbourethral glands (Cowper's). They drain into urethra below the perineal membrane
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Dorsal nerve of penis

questions.text: A patient complaint of bleeding gums and loosening teeth. His dietary history revealed that he has been consuming only fast food and no vegetable or fruit in his diet for the past 6 months. The patient is exhibiting these symptoms due to which one of the following?

choices.text: Reduced hydrogen bond formation in collagen

questions.solution:
• The patient developed scurvy owing to a lack of vitamin C in his diet.
  • Vitamin C plays the role of a coenzyme in hydroxylation of proline and lysine while protocollagen is converted to collagen. The hydroxylation reaction is catalyzed by lysyl hydroxylase (for lysine) and prolyl hydroxylase (for proline). This reaction is dependent on vitamin C, molecular oxygen and a-ketoglutarate
  • The lack of hydroxyproline reduces the stability of the collagen because of reduced hydrogen-bonding capabilities within the collagen triple helix.
  • The lack of vitamin C does not affect disulfide-bond formation, which is required to initiate triple-helix formation within the cell

questions.text:
Which of the following statement are true regarding histological features of emphysema:

There is loss of attachments of the alveoli to the outer wall of small airways
The pores of Kohn become narrower and obstructed
It causes decrease in capillary bed area
There are large abnormal airspaces, blebs and bullae
questions.solution:
Histological features of emphysema

  • Loss of attachments of the alveoli to the outer wall of small airways.
  • Pores of Kohn are enlargedthat septa appear to be floating or protrude blindly into alveolar spaces with a club-shaped end. 
  • Prolonged vasoconstriction leads to changes of pulmonary arterial hypertension.
  • Alveolar walls are destroyed → decrease in the capillary bed area.
  • With advanced disease, there are even larger abnormal airspaces and possibly blebs or bullae,→ deform and compress the respiratory bronchioles and vasculature of the lung.

Pulmonary emphysema

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient is accompanied by his wife.The patient's wife is concerned that since starting some new medications for his Parkinson's disease, he has started acting differently. She reports that since starting the new medication he has started gambling and making inappropriate sexual comments to the cleaning maid.Which medication is likely to be responsible for this new behaviour?
questions.solution:
The presentation of the patient is of disinhibition.

Ropinirole is associated with impulse control disorder (pathological gambling and hypersexuality)

Option A- (Levodopa + Carbidopa) given for management of Parkinson’s disease. it is not associated with disinhibition.

Option B- Bromocriptine -Cause Raynaud’s phenomenon, doesn’t cause any behavioral change.

Option D-Entacapone is COMT inhibitor. S/E: mainly nausea, vomitting and dyskinesia

questions.text: A patient previously diagnosed with Chronic CHF came in for regular check-up. ECG taken revealed a short QTc and given that the patient has had history of kidney stones, you suspect it could be due to hypercalcemia. Which diuretic would you pick to treat this patient such that it will help with the hypercalcemia also?
questions.solution:
Loop diuretics: Thiazide diuretics:
  • Act on Na+K+2Cl-symporter
  • acts on ascending limb of loop of Henle.
  • Includes- furosemide, torsemide, bumetanide
  • High ceiling diuretics
  • Loop looses calcium – therefore used in hypercalcemia
  • Inhibits Na-Cl-symporter
  • acts on distal tubule
  • Includes- chlorthiazide, indapamide
  • Decreases Na+, K+, Mg2+, H+
  • Increases glucose, uric acid, lipid
  • Increase in calcium – used in osteoporosis

questions.text: A 44-year-old female comes in to the emergency with complaints of difficulty in breathing, with no associated cough or fever. On examination, you notice that the RR is elevated, there is significant wheeze bilaterally. You suspect it could be an acute exacerbation of asthma,prescribe salbutamol nebulisation as the drug of choice for acute severe asthma is:-
questions.solution:
Short acting beta 2 agonists like salbutamol are drug of choice for acute severe asthma

Condition Drug of choice
Bronchial Asthma
Acute attack Salbutamol
Acute attack in pregnancy Salbutamol
Acute attack during labour Ipratropium
Acute attack in patients on beta blocker therapy. Ipratropium
Prophylaxis Corticosteroids
Exercise-induced asthma
Acute attack Salbutamol
Prophylaxis Corticosteroids
Aspirin-induced asthma
Acute attack Salbutamol
Prophylaxis Corticosteroids
Brittle asthma
Type 1 S.C. Terbutaline infusion
Type 2 S.C. Adrenaline

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient with nephrotic syndrome presents to the ER, with complaints of acute onset of breathlessness after prolonged air travel for 16 hours. On clinical examination, pulse rate is 120/min with BP=130/80mmHg. Sp02 = 85% and bedside echo show right ventricular dilation with interventricular septum deviation to the left side.What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
• Nephrotic syndrome is a hypercoagulable state. Prolonged air travel predisposes patient to the development of stasis of blood in Soleal veins. The thrombus in the deep veins can embolism to the heart and leads to pulmonary embolism.
  • The echo shows RV dyskinesia with normotension. Hence the mainstay of treatment is UFH.
  • Choice A: Thrombolysis is indicated as primary therapy in case of hypotension.
  • Choice C: Embolectomy is also done in case of hypotension in PE.
  • Choice D: Indications for insertion of an IVC filter is (1) active bleeding that precludes anticoagulation and (2) recurrent venous thrombosis despite intensive anticoagulation. The filter itself may fail by permitting the passage of small-to-medium-size clots

questions.text: A 29-year-old schizophrenic male, currently under the treatment of Haloperidol, presented with Parkinsonism like symptoms. Which of the following would you prescribe, considered to be the drug of choice for such cases?
questions.solution:
Condition Drug
DOC for Parkinsonism Pramipexole/Ropinirole
DOC for Drug induced Parkinsonism Benzhexol (Trihexiphenidyl)
Most effective drug for Parkinsonism Levo-dopa + Carbidopa
Gold standard drug for Parkinsonism Levo-dopa + Carbidopa
Disease modifying drug in Parkinsonism Selegiline

questions.text: LCAT (Lecithin Cholesterol Acyl Transferase) is an enzyme associated with HDL and converts HDL-cholesterol to HDL-cholesterol ester by adding one fatty acid in cholesterol. Which of the following is increased in LCAT deficiency?
questions.solution:
LCAT deficiency

  • Proper HDL is not formed
  • Spherical HDL ↓
  • Nascent or discoidal HDL ↑
  • Free cholesterol ↑ ( not getting incorporated in HDL)
  • RBCs have increased cholesterol content and thus hemolysis occurs
Disease Norum’s disease Fish eye disease
LCAT Complete deficiency Partial deficiency
Hemolytic Anemia Severe Absent
End stage renal disease Present Absent

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about laryngomalacia?

Anterior prolapse of arytenoid mucosa.
Short aryepiglottic folds.
Anterior collapse of the epiglottis.
Omega-shaped Epiglottis.
questions.solution:
LARYNGOSCOPIC FINDINGS OF LARYNGOMALACIA:

  • Anterior prolapse of arytenoids mucosa.
  • Short aryepiglottic folds
  • Posterior collapse of elongated epiglottis which is curled upon itself (omega-shaped).
  • Aryepiglottic folds are floppy, and arytenoids are prominent

questions.text: A patient presents with a continuous machine-like murmur. Which of the following embryonic arterial structures is most likely responsible for the origin of this murmur?
questions.solution:
• Continuous machine-like murmur presents in the case of patent ductus arteriosus
  • Proximal part of 6th arch artery – Pulmonary artery.
  • Distal part of left 6th arch artery – Ductus arteriosus

questions.text: Given below is the histopathology of liver biopsy of a patient with hemochromatosis. Which of the following special stain has been used?
questions.solution:
Perls’ Prussian blue reaction for ferric iron(Perls 1867)

  • This method is considered to be the first classical histochemical reaction.
  • Treatment with an acidic ferrocyanide solution will result in the unmasking of ferric iron in the form of the hydroxide, Fe (OH)3, by dilute hydrochloric acid.
  • The ferric iron then reacts with a dilute potassium ferrocyanide solution to produce an insoluble blue compound, ferric ferrocyanide (Prussian blue colour).
  • Perls' stain is used in histopathology todemonstrate iron (hemosiderin) in tissues.
